<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Colombia</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in South America</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Colombia_(disambiguation)" title="Colombia (disambiguation)">Colombia (disambiguation)</a> and <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Columbia_(disambiguation)" title="Columbia (disambiguation)">Columbia</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Not to be confused with <a href="/wiki/Colombo" title="Colombo">Colombo</a>.</div>
<p>
<span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1073938472">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Colombia&amp;params=4_N_72_W_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">4°N</span> <span class="longitude">72°W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">4°N 72°W</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">4; -72</span></span></span></a></span></span></span>
</p>

<sup class="reference" id="ref_iboxa"><a href="#endnote_iboxa">[a]</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Ethnic_group" title="Ethnic group">Ethnic groups</a> <div class="infobox-full-data" colspan="2"><div class="ib-country-fn"><ol class="ib-country-fn-alpha">
<li value="1"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1041539562">.mw-parser-output .citation{word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}</style><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_iboxa"><b><a href="#ref_iboxa">^</a></b></span> Although the Colombian Constitution specifies Spanish (<i>Castellano</i>) as the official language in all Colombian territory, other languages spoken in the country by ethnic groups – approximately 68 languages – each is also official in its own territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> English is also official in the <a href="/wiki/Archipelago_of_San_Andr%C3%A9s,_Providencia_and_Santa_Catalina" title="Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina">archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LEY47DE1993_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-LEY47DE1993-9">[9]</a></sup></li><li value="2"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_iboxb"><b><a href="#ref_iboxb">^</a></b></span> The official Colombian time<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> is controlled and coordinated by the National Institute of Metrology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup></li>
</ol></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Colombia</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'k' in 'kind'">k</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/ʌ/: 'u' in 'cut'">ʌ</span><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span></span>/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-Colombia-pronunciation.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/63/En-Colombia-pronunciation.ogg" title="En-Colombia-pronunciation.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>, <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/-<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/ɒ/: 'o' in 'body'">ɒ</span><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span></span>-/</a></span></span>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> <small>Spanish: </small><span class="IPA" lang="es-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">[koˈlombja]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Es-Colombia2.oga" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/76/Es-Colombia2.oga" title="Es-Colombia2.oga">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), officially the <b>Republic of Colombia</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[a]</a></sup> is a country in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a> with an <a href="/wiki/Insular_region_of_Colombia" title="Insular region of Colombia">insular region</a> in <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>. It is bordered by the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">Caribbean Sea</a> to the north, <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> to the east, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> to the southeast, <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a> to the south, the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> to the west and <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a> to the northwest. Colombia comprises 32 <a href="/wiki/Departments_of_Colombia" title="Departments of Colombia">departments</a> and the Capital District of <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">Bogotá</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Colombia_by_population" title="List of cities in Colombia by population">country's largest city</a>. It covers an area of 1,141,748 square kilometers (440,831 sq mi), with a population of 50 million. Colombia's <a href="/wiki/Cultural_heritage" title="Cultural heritage">cultural heritage</a> reflects influences by various <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">Amerindian</a> civilizations, European settlement, enslaved Africans, as well as <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Colombia" title="Immigration to Colombia">immigration</a> from Europe and the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>. <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> is the nation's <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a>, besides which <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Colombia" title="Languages of Colombia">over 70 languages</a> are spoken.
</p><p>Colombia has been inhabited by various <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">indigenous peoples</a> since at least 12,000 BCE, including the <a href="/wiki/Muisca" title="Muisca">Muisca</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quimbaya_civilization" title="Quimbaya civilization">Quimbaya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tairona" title="Tairona">Tairona</a>. The Spanish landed first in La Guajira in 1499 and by the mid-16th century <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">colonized</a> parts of the region, establishing the <a href="/wiki/New_Kingdom_of_Granada" title="New Kingdom of Granada">New Kingdom of Granada</a>, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santa_F%C3%A9_de_Bogot%C3%A1" title="Santa Fé de Bogotá">Santa Fé de Bogotá</a> as its capital. <a href="/wiki/Spanish_American_wars_of_independence" title="Spanish American wars of independence">Independence</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> was achieved in 1819, with what is now Colombia emerging as the <a href="/wiki/United_Provinces_of_New_Granada" title="United Provinces of New Granada">United Provinces of New Granada</a>. The new nation experimented with federalism as the <a href="/wiki/Granadine_Confederation" title="Granadine Confederation">Granadine Confederation</a> (1858) and then the <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Colombia" title="United States of Colombia">United States of Colombia</a> (1863), before the Republic of Colombia was finally declared in 1886. <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_Panama_from_Colombia" title="Separation of Panama from Colombia">Panama seceded</a> in 1903, leading to Colombia's present borders. Beginning in the 1960s, the country has suffered from an asymmetric low-intensity <a href="/wiki/Colombian_conflict" title="Colombian conflict">armed conflict</a> and political violence, both of which escalated in the 1990s. Since 2005, there has been significant improvement in security, stability and rule of law, as well as unprecedented economic growth and development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enough_Already!_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-Enough_Already!-15">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombia's_GDP_growth_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombia's_GDP_growth-16">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>Colombia is one of the world's seventeen <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse countries</a>; it has the second-highest level of <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_of_Colombia" title="Biodiversity of Colombia">biodiversity</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Biodiversity_of_Colombia_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-Biodiversity_of_Colombia-17">[15]</a></sup> Its territory encompasses <a href="/wiki/Amazon_natural_region" title="Amazon natural region">Amazon rainforest</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andean_natural_region" title="Andean natural region">highlands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orinoqu%C3%ADa_natural_region" title="Orinoquía natural region">grasslands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tatacoa_Desert" title="Tatacoa Desert">deserts</a>. It is the only country in South America with coastlines and islands along both the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_natural_region" title="Caribbean natural region">Atlantic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pacific/Choc%C3%B3_natural_region" title="Pacific/Chocó natural region">Pacific</a> oceans.
</p><p>Colombia is a member of major global and regional organizations including the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">UN</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">OAS</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Alliance" title="Pacific Alliance">Pacific Alliance</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Andean_Community" title="Andean Community">Andean Community</a>. It is also a <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> Global Partner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[16]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Colombia" title="Economy of Colombia">diversified economy</a> is the third-largest in South America, with macroeconomic stability and favorable long-term growth prospects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDP_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-GDP-19">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-strongmacroeconomicmanagement_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-strongmacroeconomicmanagement-20">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The name "Colombia" is derived from the last name of the Italian navigator <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> (<a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a>: <i lang="it">Cristoforo Colombo</i>, Spanish: <i lang="es">Cristóbal Colón</i>). It was conceived as a reference to all of the New World.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[19]</a></sup> The name was later adopted by the <a href="/wiki/Gran_Colombia" title="Gran Colombia">Republic of Colombia</a> of 1819, formed from the territories of the old <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Granada" title="Viceroyalty of New Granada">Viceroyalty of New Granada</a> (modern-day Colombia, Panama, Venezuela, Ecuador, and northwest Brazil).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LABLAA5_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-LABLAA5-22">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>When Venezuela, Ecuador, and <a href="/wiki/Cundinamarca_Department_(1820)" title="Cundinamarca Department (1820)">Cundinamarca</a> came to exist as independent states, the former <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_the_Republic_of_New_Granada" title="Provinces of the Republic of New Granada">Department of Cundinamarca</a> adopted the name "<a href="/wiki/Republic_of_New_Granada" title="Republic of New Granada">Republic of New Granada</a>". New Granada officially changed its name in 1858 to the <a href="/wiki/Granadine_Confederation" title="Granadine Confederation">Granadine Confederation</a>. In 1863 the name was again changed, this time to <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Colombia" title="United States of Colombia">United States of Colombia</a>, before finally adopting its present name – the Republic of Colombia – in 1886.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LABLAA5_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-LABLAA5-22">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>To refer to this country, the Colombian government uses the terms <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Colombia</i></span> and <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">República de Colombia</i></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Colombia" title="History of Colombia">History of Colombia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Colombian_history" title="Timeline of Colombian history">Timeline of Colombian history</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Columbian_era">Pre-Columbian era</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_cultures_of_Colombia" title="Pre-Columbian cultures of Colombia">Pre-Columbian cultures of Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Culture_pr%C3%A9colombiennes_en_Colombie.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="745" data-file-width="646" decoding="async" height="254" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Culture_pr%C3%A9colombiennes_en_Colombie.png/220px-Culture_pr%C3%A9colombiennes_en_Colombie.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Culture_pr%C3%A9colombiennes_en_Colombie.png/330px-Culture_pr%C3%A9colombiennes_en_Colombie.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Culture_pr%C3%A9colombiennes_en_Colombie.png/440px-Culture_pr%C3%A9colombiennes_en_Colombie.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Culture_pr%C3%A9colombiennes_en_Colombie.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Location map of the pre-Columbian cultures of Colombia</div></div></div>
<p>Owing to its location, the present territory of Colombia was a corridor of early human civilization from <a href="/wiki/Mesoamerica" title="Mesoamerica">Mesoamerica</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">Andes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amazon_basin" title="Amazon basin">Amazon basin</a>. The oldest archaeological finds are from the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Pubenza_archaeological_site&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Pubenza archaeological site (page does not exist)">Pubenza</a> and <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=El_Totumo_archaeological_site&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="El Totumo archaeological site (page does not exist)">El Totumo</a> sites in the Magdalena Valley 100 kilometers (62 mi) southwest of Bogotá.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[22]</a></sup> These sites date from the <a href="/wiki/Paleo-Indians" title="Paleo-Indians">Paleoindian</a> period (18,000–8000 BCE). At <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Hormiga_archaeological_site" title="Puerto Hormiga archaeological site">Puerto Hormiga</a> and other sites, traces from the <a href="/wiki/Archaic_Period_(Americas)" title="Archaic Period (Americas)">Archaic Period</a> (~8000–2000 BCE) have been found. Vestiges indicate that there was also early occupation in the regions of <a href="/wiki/El_Abra" title="El Abra">El Abra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tequendama" title="Tequendama">Tequendama</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cundinamarca_Department" title="Cundinamarca Department">Cundinamarca</a>. The oldest pottery discovered in the Americas, found at San Jacinto, dates to 5000–4000 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[23]</a></sup>
</p><p>Indigenous people inhabited the territory that is now Colombia by 12,500 BCE. Nomadic <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherer</a> tribes at the El Abra, <a href="/wiki/Tibit%C3%B3" title="Tibitó">Tibitó</a> and Tequendama sites near present-day <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">Bogotá</a> traded with one another and with other cultures from the <a href="/wiki/Magdalena_River" title="Magdalena River">Magdalena River</a> Valley.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[24]</a></sup> A site including eight miles (13 km) of <a href="/wiki/Pictogram" title="Pictogram">pictographs</a> that is under study at Serranía de la Lindosa was revealed in November 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[25]</a></sup> Their age is suggested as being 12,500 years old (c. 10,480 B.C.) by the anthropologists working on the site because of extinct fauna depicted. That would have been during the earliest known human occupation of the area now known as Colombia.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Between 5000 and 1000 BCE, hunter-gatherer tribes transitioned to agrarian societies; fixed settlements were established, and pottery appeared. Beginning in the 1st millennium BCE, groups of <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">Amerindians</a> including the <a href="/wiki/Muisca" title="Muisca">Muisca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zen%C3%BA" title="Zenú">Zenú</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quimbaya_civilization" title="Quimbaya civilization">Quimbaya</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tairona" title="Tairona">Tairona</a> developed the political system of <i><a href="/wiki/Cacicazgo" title="Cacicazgo">cacicazgos</a></i> with a pyramidal structure of power headed by <i>caciques</i>. The Muisca inhabited mainly the area of what is now the <a href="/wiki/Departments_of_Colombia" title="Departments of Colombia">Departments</a> of <a href="/wiki/Boyac%C3%A1_Department" title="Boyacá Department">Boyacá</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cundinamarca_Department" title="Cundinamarca Department">Cundinamarca</a> high plateau (<i><a href="/wiki/Altiplano_Cundiboyacense" title="Altiplano Cundiboyacense">Altiplano Cundiboyacense</a></i>) where they formed the <a href="/wiki/Muisca_Confederation" title="Muisca Confederation">Muisca Confederation</a>. They farmed maize, potato, quinoa, and cotton, and traded gold, <a href="/wiki/Colombian_emeralds" title="Colombian emeralds">emeralds</a>, blankets, ceramic handicrafts, coca and especially <a href="/wiki/Halite" title="Halite">rock salt</a> with neighboring nations. The Tairona inhabited northern Colombia in the isolated mountain range of <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_de_Santa_Marta" title="Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta">Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[26]</a></sup> The Quimbaya inhabited regions of the <a href="/wiki/Cauca_River" title="Cauca River">Cauca River</a> Valley between the <a href="/wiki/Cordillera_Occidental_(Colombia)" title="Cordillera Occidental (Colombia)">Western</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cordillera_Central_(Colombia)" title="Cordillera Central (Colombia)">Central</a> Ranges of the Colombian Andes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[27]</a></sup> Most of the Amerindians practiced agriculture and the social structure of each indigenous community was different. Some groups of indigenous people such as the Caribs lived in a state of permanent war, but others had less bellicose attitudes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[28]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_annexation">European annexation</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Alonso_de_Ojeda" title="Alonso de Ojeda">Alonso de Ojeda</a> (who had sailed with Columbus) reached the <a href="/wiki/Guajira_Peninsula" title="Guajira Peninsula">Guajira Peninsula</a> in 1499.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LABLAA6_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-LABLAA6-31">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[30]</a></sup> Spanish explorers, led by <a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_de_Bastidas" title="Rodrigo de Bastidas">Rodrigo de Bastidas</a>, made the first exploration of the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Basin" title="Caribbean Basin">Caribbean coast</a> in 1500.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[31]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> navigated near the Caribbean in 1502.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[32]</a></sup> In 1508, <a href="/wiki/Vasco_N%C3%BA%C3%B1ez_de_Balboa" title="Vasco Núñez de Balboa">Vasco Núñez de Balboa</a> accompanied an expedition to the territory through the region of <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Urab%C3%A1" title="Gulf of Urabá">Gulf of Urabá</a> and they founded the town of <a href="/wiki/Santa_Mar%C3%ADa_la_Antigua_del_Dari%C3%A9n" title="Santa María la Antigua del Darién">Santa María la Antigua del Darién</a> in 1510, the first stable settlement on the continent. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[Note 2]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Santa_Marta" title="Santa Marta">Santa Marta</a> was founded in 1525,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[34]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">Cartagena</a> in 1533.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[35]</a></sup> Spanish <a href="/wiki/Conquistador" title="Conquistador">conquistador</a> <a href="/wiki/Gonzalo_Jim%C3%A9nez_de_Quesada" title="Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada">Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada</a> led an expedition to the interior in April 1536, and christened the districts through which he passed "<a href="/wiki/New_Kingdom_of_Granada" title="New Kingdom of Granada">New Kingdom of Granada</a>". In August 1538, he founded provisionally its capital near the Muisca <a href="/wiki/Cacicazgo" title="Cacicazgo">cacicazgo</a> of <a href="/wiki/Bacat%C3%A1" title="Bacatá">Muyquytá</a>, and named it "Santa Fe". The name soon acquired a suffix and was called Santa Fe de Bogotá.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[37]</a></sup> Two other notable journeys by early conquistadors to the interior took place in the same period. <a href="/wiki/Sebasti%C3%A1n_de_Belalc%C3%A1zar" title="Sebastián de Belalcázar">Sebastián de Belalcázar</a>, conqueror of <a href="/wiki/Quito" title="Quito">Quito</a>, traveled north and founded <a href="/wiki/Cali" title="Cali">Cali</a>, in 1536, and <a href="/wiki/Popay%C3%A1n" title="Popayán">Popayán</a>, in 1537;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[38]</a></sup> from 1536 to 1539, German conquistador <a href="/wiki/Nikolaus_Federmann" title="Nikolaus Federmann">Nikolaus Federmann</a> crossed the <a href="/wiki/Orinoqu%C3%ADa_natural_region" title="Orinoquía natural region">Llanos Orientales</a> and went over the <a href="/wiki/Cordillera_Oriental_(Colombia)" title="Cordillera Oriental (Colombia)">Cordillera Oriental</a> in a search for <a href="/wiki/El_Dorado" title="El Dorado">El Dorado</a>, the "city of gold".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[39]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[40]</a></sup> The legend and the gold would play a pivotal role in luring the Spanish and other Europeans to New Granada during the 16th and 17th centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/List_of_conquistadors_in_Colombia" title="List of conquistadors in Colombia">conquistadors</a> made frequent alliances with the enemies of different indigenous communities. <a href="/wiki/Indian_auxiliaries" title="Indian auxiliaries">Indigenous allies</a> were crucial to conquest, as well as to creating and maintaining empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[42]</a></sup> Indigenous peoples in New Granada experienced a decline in population due to conquest as well as Eurasian diseases, such as <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a>, to which they had no immunity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[44]</a></sup> Regarding the land as deserted, the Spanish Crown sold properties to all persons interested in colonized territories, creating large farms and possession of mines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TierrasColonia_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-TierrasColonia-48">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EconomíaColonial_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-EconomíaColonial-49">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-políticaeconómica_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-políticaeconómica-50">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 16th century, the <a href="/wiki/Navigation" title="Navigation">nautical science</a> in Spain reached a great development thanks to numerous scientific figures of the <a href="/wiki/Casa_de_Contrataci%C3%B3n" title="Casa de Contratación">Casa de Contratación</a> and nautical science was an essential pillar of the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_ship_development,_1400%E2%80%931600" title="Iberian ship development, 1400–1600">Iberian expansion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alonso_de_Santa_Cruz_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-Alonso_de_Santa_Cruz-51">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_exchange">Colonial exchange</span></h3>
<p>In 1542, the region of New Granada, along with all other Spanish possessions in South America, became part of the <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_Peru" title="Viceroyalty of Peru">Viceroyalty of Peru</a>, with its capital in <a href="/wiki/Lima" title="Lima">Lima</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[49]</a></sup> In 1547, New Granada became a separate captaincy-general within the viceroyalty, with its capital at Santa Fe de Bogota.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1549, the <a href="/wiki/Real_Audiencia" title="Real Audiencia">Royal Audiencia</a> was created by a royal decree, and New Granada was ruled by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Audience_of_Santa_Fe_de_Bogot%C3%A1" title="Royal Audience of Santa Fe de Bogotá">Royal Audience of Santa Fe de Bogotá</a>, which at that time comprised the provinces of Santa Marta, Rio de San Juan, Popayán, Guayana and Cartagena.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[51]</a></sup> But important decisions were taken from the colony to Spain by the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_Indies" title="Council of the Indies">Council of the Indies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo,_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="795" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg/220px-Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg/330px-Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg/440px-Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo,_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An illustration of the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cartagena_de_Indias" title="Battle of Cartagena de Indias">Battle of Cartagena de Indias</a>, a major Spanish victory in the <a href="/wiki/War_of_Jenkins%27_Ear" title="War of Jenkins' Ear">War of Jenkins' Ear</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BattleofCartagena_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-BattleofCartagena-57">[54]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In the 16th century, European slave traders had begun to bring <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">enslaved Africans</a> to the Americas. Spain was the only European power that did not establish <a href="/wiki/Factory_(trading_post)" title="Factory (trading post)">factories</a> in Africa to purchase slaves; the Spanish Empire instead relied on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asiento" title="Asiento">asiento</a> system, awarding merchants from other European nations the license to trade enslaved peoples to their overseas territories.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[56]</a></sup> This system brought Africans to Colombia, although many spoke out against the institution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[Note 3]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[Note 4]</a></sup> The indigenous peoples could not be enslaved because they were legally <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commoners" title="Commoners">subjects</a> of the Spanish Crown.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[61]</a></sup> To protect the indigenous peoples, several forms of land ownership and regulation were established by the Spanish colonial authorities: <i>resguardos</i>, <i>encomiendas</i> and <i>haciendas</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TierrasColonia_48-1"><a href="#cite_note-TierrasColonia-48">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EconomíaColonial_49-1"><a href="#cite_note-EconomíaColonial-49">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-políticaeconómica_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-políticaeconómica-50">[47]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="1536" decoding="async" height="267" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg/200px-Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg/300px-Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg/400px-Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Many intellectual leaders of the independence process participated in the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Botanical_Expedition_to_New_Granada" title="Royal Botanical Expedition to New Granada">Royal Botanical Expedition to New Granada</a>.</div></div></div><p> However, secret anti-Spanish discontentment was already brewing for Colombians since Spain prohibited direct trade between the <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_Peru" title="Viceroyalty of Peru">Viceroyalty of Peru</a>, which included Colombia, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Spain" title="Viceroyalty of New Spain">Viceroyalty of New Spain</a>, which included the Philippines, the source of Asian products like silk and porcelain which was in demand in the Americas. Illegal trade between Peruvians, Filipinos, and Mexicans continued in secret, as smuggled Asian goods ended up in <a href="/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba_Department" title="Córdoba Department">Córdoba, Colombia</a>, the distribution center for illegal Asian imports, due to the collusion between these peoples against the authorities in Spain. They settled and traded with each other while disobeying the forced Spanish monopoly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[62]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Granada" title="Viceroyalty of New Granada">Viceroyalty of New Granada</a> was established in 1717, then temporarily removed, and then re-established in 1739. Its capital was Santa Fé de Bogotá. This Viceroyalty included some other provinces of northwestern South America that had previously been under the jurisdiction of the <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">Viceroyalties of New Spain</a> or <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_Peru" title="Viceroyalty of Peru">Peru</a> and correspond mainly to today's Venezuela, Ecuador, and Panama. So, Bogotá became one of the principal administrative centers of the Spanish possessions in the New World, along with <a href="/wiki/Lima" title="Lima">Lima</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">Mexico City</a>, though it remained somewhat backward compared to those two cities in several economic and logistical ways.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">Great Britain</a> declared war <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_of_Jenkins_Ear" title="War of Jenkins Ear">on Spain</a> in 1739, and the city of Cartagena quickly became a top target for the British. A massive British expeditionary force was dispatched to capture the city, but after initial inroads devastating outbreaks of disease crippled their numbers and the British were forced to withdraw. The battle became one of Spain's most decisive victories in the conflict, and secured Spanish dominance in the Caribbean until the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BattleofCartagena_57-1"><a href="#cite_note-BattleofCartagena-57">[54]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 18th-century priest, botanist and mathematician <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis" title="José Celestino Mutis">José Celestino Mutis</a> was delegated by Viceroy <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Caballero_y_G%C3%B3ngora" title="Antonio Caballero y Góngora">Antonio Caballero y Góngora</a> to conduct an inventory of the nature of New Granada. Started in 1783, this became known as the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Botanical_Expedition_to_New_Granada" title="Royal Botanical Expedition to New Granada">Royal Botanical Expedition to New Granada</a>. It classified plants and wildlife, and founded the first astronomical observatory in the city of Santa Fe de Bogotá.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[66]</a></sup> In July 1801 the Prussian scientist <a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt" title="Alexander von Humboldt">Alexander von Humboldt</a> reached Santa Fe de Bogotá where he met with Mutis. In addition, historical figures in the process of independence in New Granada emerged from the expedition as the astronomer <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Jos%C3%A9_de_Caldas" title="Francisco José de Caldas">Francisco José de Caldas</a>, the scientist <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Antonio_Zea" title="Francisco Antonio Zea">Francisco Antonio Zea</a>, the zoologist <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Tadeo_Lozano" title="Jorge Tadeo Lozano">Jorge Tadeo Lozano</a> and the painter <a href="/wiki/Salvador_Rizo" title="Salvador Rizo">Salvador Rizo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[68]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence">Independence</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1122" data-file-width="1654" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg/220px-Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg/330px-Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg/440px-Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Boyac%C3%A1" title="Battle of Boyacá">Battle of Boyacá</a> was the decisive battle that ensured success of the <a href="/wiki/Bol%C3%ADvar%27s_campaign_to_liberate_New_Granada" title="Bolívar's campaign to liberate New Granada">liberation campaign of New Granada.</a></div></div></div>
<p>Since the beginning of the periods of conquest and colonization, there were several rebel movements against Spanish rule, but most were either crushed or remained too weak to change the overall situation. The last one that sought outright independence from Spain sprang up around 1810 and culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Colombian Declaration of Independence">Colombian Declaration of Independence</a>, issued on 20 July 1810, the day that is now celebrated as the nation's Independence Day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[69]</a></sup> This movement followed the independence of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Domingue" title="St. Domingue">St. Domingue</a> (present-day Haiti) in 1804, which provided some support to an eventual leader of this rebellion: <a href="/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar" title="Simón Bolívar">Simón Bolívar</a>. <a href="/wiki/Francisco_de_Paula_Santander" title="Francisco de Paula Santander">Francisco de Paula Santander</a> also would play a decisive role.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[72]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ProvinciaSocorro.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="322" data-file-width="263" decoding="async" height="184" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/ProvinciaSocorro.jpg/150px-ProvinciaSocorro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/ProvinciaSocorro.jpg/225px-ProvinciaSocorro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/ProvinciaSocorro.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ProvinciaSocorro.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Socorro_Province" title="Socorro Province">Socorro Province</a> was the site of the <a href="/wiki/Revolt_of_the_Comuneros_(New_Granada)" title="Revolt of the Comuneros (New Granada)">genesis</a> of the independence process.</div></div></div>
<p>A movement was initiated by <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Nari%C3%B1o" title="Antonio Nariño">Antonio Nariño</a>, who opposed Spanish centralism and led the opposition against the <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty" title="Viceroyalty">Viceroyalty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[73]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">Cartagena</a> became independent in November 1811.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[74]</a></sup> In 1811, the <a href="/wiki/United_Provinces_of_New_Granada" title="United Provinces of New Granada">United Provinces of New Granada</a> were proclaimed, headed by <a href="/wiki/Camilo_Torres_Tenorio" title="Camilo Torres Tenorio">Camilo Torres Tenorio</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[76]</a></sup> The emergence of two distinct ideological currents among the patriots (<a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">centralism</a>) gave rise to a period of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Patria_Boba" title="Patria Boba">instability</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[77]</a></sup> Shortly after the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> ended, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ferdinand_VII" title="Ferdinand VII">Ferdinand VII</a>, recently restored to the throne in Spain, unexpectedly decided <a href="/wiki/Spanish_reconquest_of_New_Granada" title="Spanish reconquest of New Granada">to send military forces</a> to retake most of northern South America. The viceroyalty was restored under the command of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Juan_S%C3%A1mano" title="Juan Sámano">Juan Sámano</a>, whose regime punished those who participated in the patriotic movements, ignoring the political nuances of the <a href="/wiki/Junta_(Spanish_American_Independence)" title="Junta (Spanish American Independence)">juntas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[78]</a></sup> The retribution stoked renewed rebellion, which, combined with a weakened Spain, made possible a successful rebellion led by the Venezuelan-born <a href="/wiki/Military_career_of_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar" title="Military career of Simón Bolívar">Simón Bolívar</a>, who finally proclaimed <a href="/wiki/Spanish_American_wars_of_independence" title="Spanish American wars of independence">independence</a> in 1819.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Historia_ilustrada_de_Colombia_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-Historia_ilustrada_de_Colombia-84">[79]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[80]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royalist_(Spanish_American_Independence)" title="Royalist (Spanish American Independence)">pro-Spanish resistance</a> was defeated in 1822 in the present territory of Colombia and in 1823 in Venezuela.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[83]</a></sup>
</p><p>The territory of the Viceroyalty of New Granada became the <a href="/wiki/Gran_Colombia" title="Gran Colombia">Republic of Colombia</a>, organized as a <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Gran_Colombia" title="Subdivisions of Gran Colombia">union of the current territories</a> of Colombia, Panama, Ecuador, Venezuela, parts of Guyana and Brazil and north of <a href="/wiki/Mara%C3%B1%C3%B3n_River" title="Marañón River">Marañón River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[84]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_C%C3%BAcuta" title="Congress of Cúcuta">Congress of Cúcuta</a> in 1821 adopted a <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Constitution_of_1821" title="Colombian Constitution of 1821">constitution</a> for the new Republic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[86]</a></sup> Simón Bolívar became the first <a href="/wiki/President_of_Colombia" title="President of Colombia">President of Colombia</a>, and Francisco de Paula Santander was made <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_Colombia" title="Vice President of Colombia">Vice President</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[87]</a></sup> However, the new republic was unstable and the Gran Colombia ultimately collapsed.
</p><p>Modern Colombia comes from one of the countries that emerged after the dissolution of la Gran Colombia, the other two being Ecuador and Venezuela.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EtHisColombia_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-EtHisColombia-93">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GranColombiaNuevaGranada_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-GranColombiaNuevaGranada-94">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[90]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1154" data-file-width="1082" decoding="async" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif/220px-Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif/330px-Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif/440px-Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Formation of the present Colombia since the <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Granada" title="Viceroyalty of New Granada">Viceroyalty of New Granada</a>'s independence from the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a></div></div></div>
<p>Colombia was the first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitutional_government" title="Constitutional government">constitutional government</a> in South America,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HistoriaConstitucional_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-HistoriaConstitucional-96">[91]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Liberal_Party" title="Colombian Liberal Party">Liberal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Conservative_Party" title="Colombian Conservative Party">Conservative</a> parties, founded in 1848 and 1849, respectively, are two of the oldest surviving political parties in the Americas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[92]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">Slavery</a> was abolished in the country in 1851.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>Internal political and territorial divisions led to the dissolution of <a href="/wiki/Gran_Colombia" title="Gran Colombia">Gran Colombia</a> in 1830.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EtHisColombia_93-1"><a href="#cite_note-EtHisColombia-93">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GranColombiaNuevaGranada_94-1"><a href="#cite_note-GranColombiaNuevaGranada-94">[89]</a></sup> The so-called "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cundinamarca_Province" title="Cundinamarca Province">Department of Cundinamarca</a>" adopted the name "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_the_New_Granada" title="Republic of the New Granada">New Granada</a>", which it kept until 1858 when it became the "Confederación Granadina" (<a href="/wiki/Granadine_Confederation" title="Granadine Confederation">Granadine Confederation</a>). After a <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Civil_War_(1860%E2%80%931862)" title="Colombian Civil War (1860–1862)">two-year civil war</a> in 1863, the "<a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Colombia" title="United States of Colombia">United States of Colombia</a>" was created, lasting until 1886, when the country finally became known as the Republic of Colombia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HistoriaConstitucional_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-HistoriaConstitucional-96">[91]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[95]</a></sup> Internal divisions remained between the bipartisan political forces, occasionally igniting very bloody civil wars, the most significant being the <a href="/wiki/Thousand_Days%27_War" title="Thousand Days' War">Thousand Days' War</a> (1899–1902).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="20th_century">20th century</span></h3>
<p>The United States of America's intentions to influence the area (especially the <a href="/wiki/Panama_Canal" title="Panama Canal">Panama Canal</a> construction and control)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[97]</a></sup> led to the <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_Panama_from_Colombia" title="Separation of Panama from Colombia">separation of the Department of Panama</a> in 1903 and the establishment of it as a nation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SeparationofPanama_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-SeparationofPanama-103">[98]</a></sup> The United States paid Colombia $25,000,000 in 1921, seven years after completion of the canal, for redress of President <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt" title="Theodore Roosevelt">Roosevelt</a>'s role in the creation of Panama, and Colombia recognized Panama under the terms of the <a href="/wiki/Thomson%E2%80%93Urrutia_Treaty" title="Thomson–Urrutia Treaty">Thomson–Urrutia Treaty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[99]</a></sup> Colombia and Peru went to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leticia_Incident" title="Leticia Incident">war</a> because of territory disputes far in the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_basin" title="Amazon basin">Amazon basin</a>. The war ended with a peace deal brokered by the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a>. The League finally awarded the disputed area to Colombia in June 1934.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bogotazo.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="244" data-file-width="391" decoding="async" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Bogotazo.jpg/220px-Bogotazo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Bogotazo.jpg/330px-Bogotazo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/57/Bogotazo.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bogotazo.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Bogotazo" title="Bogotazo">Bogotazo</a> in 1948</div></div></div>
<p>Soon after, Colombia achieved some degree of political stability, which was interrupted by a bloody conflict that took place between the late 1940s and the early 1950s, a period known as <i><a href="/wiki/La_Violencia" title="La Violencia">La Violencia</a></i> ("The Violence"). Its cause was mainly mounting tensions between the two leading political parties, which subsequently ignited after the assassination of the Liberal presidential candidate <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Eli%C3%A9cer_Gait%C3%A1n" title="Jorge Eliécer Gaitán">Jorge Eliécer Gaitán</a> on 9 April 1948.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[101]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[102]</a></sup> The ensuing riots in Bogotá, known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/El_Bogotazo" title="El Bogotazo">El Bogotazo</a>, spread throughout the country and claimed the lives of at least 180,000 Colombians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta-108">[103]</a></sup>
</p><p>Colombia entered the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a> when <a href="/wiki/Laureano_G%C3%B3mez" title="Laureano Gómez">Laureano Gómez</a> was elected president. It was the only Latin American country to join the war in a direct military role as an ally of the United States. Particularly important was the resistance of the Colombian troops at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Old_Baldy" title="Battle of Old Baldy">Old Baldy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombia's_legacy_with_Korea_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombia's_legacy_with_Korea-109">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p>The violence between the two political parties decreased first when <a href="/wiki/Gustavo_Rojas_Pinilla" title="Gustavo Rojas Pinilla">Gustavo Rojas</a> deposed the <a href="/wiki/Laureano_G%C3%B3mez" title="Laureano Gómez">President</a> of Colombia in a coup d'état and negotiated with the guerrillas, and then under the <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Military_Junta" title="Colombian Military Junta">military junta</a> of General <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gabriel_Par%C3%ADs" title="Gabriel París">Gabriel París</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3134" data-file-width="4232" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg/220px-Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg/330px-Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg/440px-Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Axis of Peace and Memory, a memorial to the victims of the <a href="/wiki/Colombian_conflict" title="Colombian conflict">Colombian conflict</a> (1964–present)</div></div></div>
<p>After Rojas' deposition, the Colombian Conservative Party and Colombian Liberal Party agreed to create the <a href="/wiki/National_Front_(Colombia)" title="National Front (Colombia)">National Front</a>, a coalition that would jointly govern the country. Under the deal, the presidency would alternate between conservatives and liberals every 4 years for 16 years; the two parties would have parity in all other elective offices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[107]</a></sup> The National Front ended "La Violencia", and National Front administrations attempted to institute far-reaching social and economic reforms in cooperation with the <a href="/wiki/Alliance_for_Progress" title="Alliance for Progress">Alliance for Progress</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[109]</a></sup> Despite the progress in certain sectors, many social and political problems continued, and guerrilla groups were formally created such as the <a href="/wiki/Revolutionary_Armed_Forces_of_Colombia" title="Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia">FARC</a>, the <a href="/wiki/National_Liberation_Army_(Colombia)" title="National Liberation Army (Colombia)">ELN</a> and the <a href="/wiki/19th_of_April_Movement" title="19th of April Movement">M-19</a> to fight the government and political apparatus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the 1960s, the country has suffered from an <a href="/wiki/Asymmetric_warfare" title="Asymmetric warfare">asymmetric</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Low_intensity_conflict" title="Low intensity conflict">low-intensity</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_armed_conflict_(1964%E2%80%93present)" title="Colombian armed conflict (1964–present)">armed conflict</a> between <a href="/wiki/Military_Forces_of_Colombia" title="Military Forces of Colombia">government forces</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guerrilla_movements_in_Colombia" title="Guerrilla movements in Colombia">leftist guerrilla groups</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paramilitarism_in_Colombia" title="Paramilitarism in Colombia">right wing paramilitaries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HistoricalCommission_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-HistoricalCommission-116">[111]</a></sup> The conflict escalated in the 1990s,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_armed_conflict_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_armed_conflict-117">[112]</a></sup> mainly in remote rural areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_conflict_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_conflict-118">[113]</a></sup> Since the beginning of the armed conflict, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_rights_defenders" title="Human rights defenders">human rights defenders</a> have fought for the respect for human rights, despite staggering opposition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[Note 5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[Note 6]</a></sup> Several guerrillas' organizations decided to demobilize after peace negotiations in 1989–1994.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enough_Already!_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-Enough_Already!-15">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>The United States has been heavily involved in the conflict since its beginnings, when in the early 1960s the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._government" title="U.S. government">U.S. government</a> encouraged the Colombian military to attack leftist militias in rural Colombia. This was part of the U.S. fight against communism. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mercenarie" title="Mercenarie">Mercenaries</a> and multinational corporations such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chiquita_Brands_International" title="Chiquita Brands International">Chiquita Brands International</a> are some of the international actors that have contributed to the violence of the conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HistoricalCommission_116-1"><a href="#cite_note-HistoricalCommission-116">[111]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enough_Already!_15-2"><a href="#cite_note-Enough_Already!-15">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-colombia-and-us-54_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-colombia-and-us-54-124">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beginning in the mid-1970s Colombian <a href="/wiki/Drug_cartel" title="Drug cartel">drug cartels</a> became major producers, processors and exporters of <a href="/wiki/Illegal_drug_trade_in_Colombia" title="Illegal drug trade in Colombia">illegal drugs</a>, primarily <a href="/wiki/Cannabis_(drug)" title="Cannabis (drug)">marijuana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[118]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 4 July 1991, a new <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Constitution_of_1991" title="Colombian Constitution of 1991">Constitution</a> was promulgated. The changes generated by the new constitution are viewed as positive by Colombian society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[119]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_Constitution_of_1991_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_Constitution_of_1991-127">[120]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="21st_century">21st century</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._(29953487045).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2206" data-file-width="3307" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._%2829953487045%29.jpg/230px-Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._%2829953487045%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._%2829953487045%29.jpg/345px-Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._%2829953487045%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._%2829953487045%29.jpg/460px-Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._%2829953487045%29.jpg 2x" width="230"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._(29953487045).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Former President <a href="/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Santos" title="Juan Manuel Santos">Juan Manuel Santos</a> signed a <a href="/wiki/Colombian_peace_process" title="Colombian peace process">peace accord</a></div></div></div>
<p>The administration of President <a href="/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Uribe" title="Álvaro Uribe">Álvaro Uribe</a> (2002–2010), adopted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Democratic_security_policy" title="Democratic security policy">democratic security policy</a> which included an integrated <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Counter-terrorism" title="Counter-terrorism">counter-terrorism</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Counter-insurgency" title="Counter-insurgency">counter-insurgency</a> campaign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[121]</a></sup> The Government economic plan also promoted confidence in investors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[122]</a></sup> As part of a controversial peace process the <a href="/wiki/United_Self-Defense_Forces_of_Colombia" title="United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia">AUC</a> (right-wing paramilitaries) as a formal organization had ceased to function.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAWFB_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIAWFB-130">[123]</a></sup> In February 2008, millions of Colombians demonstrated against FARC and other outlawed groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>After peace negotiations in <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Colombia" title="Government of Colombia">Colombian government</a> of President <a href="/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Santos" title="Juan Manuel Santos">Juan Manuel Santos</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guerrillas" title="Guerrillas">guerrillas</a> of the FARC-EP announced a final agreement to end the conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[125]</a></sup> However, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_peace_agreement_referendum,_2016" title="Colombian peace agreement referendum, 2016">referendum</a> to ratify the deal was unsuccessful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[127]</a></sup> Afterward, the Colombian government and the FARC signed a revised <a href="/wiki/Colombian_peace_process" title="Colombian peace process">peace deal</a> in November 2016,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[128]</a></sup> which the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_congress" title="Colombian congress">Colombian congress</a> approved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[129]</a></sup> In 2016, President Santos was awarded the <a href="/wiki/2016_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2016 Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[130]</a></sup> The Government began a process of attention and comprehensive reparation for victims of conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[131]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[132]</a></sup> Colombia shows modest progress in the struggle to defend human rights, as expressed by <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">HRW</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[133]</a></sup> A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Special_Jurisdiction_of_Peace" title="Special Jurisdiction of Peace">Special Jurisdiction of Peace</a> has been created to investigate, clarify, prosecute and punish serious human rights violations and grave breaches of <a href="/wiki/International_humanitarian_law" title="International humanitarian law">international humanitarian law</a> which occurred during the armed conflict and to satisfy victims' right to <a href="/wiki/Justice" title="Justice">justice</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[134]</a></sup> During his visit to Colombia, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a> paid tribute to the victims of the conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[135]</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2018, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ivan_Duque" title="Ivan Duque">Ivan Duque</a>, the candidate of the right-wing <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Center_(Colombia)" title="Democratic Center (Colombia)">Democratic Center</a> party, won the presidential <a href="/wiki/2018_Colombian_presidential_election" title="2018 Colombian presidential election">election</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[136]</a></sup> On 7 August 2018, he was sworn in as the new <a href="/wiki/President_of_Colombia" title="President of Colombia">President of Colombia</a> to succeed Juan Manuel Santos.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/2010_Colombia%E2%80%93Venezuela_diplomatic_crisis" title="2010 Colombia–Venezuela diplomatic crisis">Colombia's relations with Venezuela</a> have fluctuated due to ideological differences between the two governments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[138]</a></sup> Colombia has offered <a href="/wiki/Humanitarian_aid" title="Humanitarian aid">humanitarian support</a> with food and medicines to mitigate the shortage of supplies in Venezuela.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[139]</a></sup> Colombia's Foreign Ministry said that all efforts to resolve <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crisis_in_Venezuela_(2012%E2%80%93present)" title="Crisis in Venezuela (2012–present)">Venezuela's crisis</a> should be peaceful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[140]</a></sup> Colombia proposed the idea of the <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_Development_Goals" title="Sustainable Development Goals">Sustainable Development Goals</a> and a final document was adopted by the United Nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[141]</a></sup> In February 2019, Venezuelan president <a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro" title="Nicolás Maduro">Nicolás Maduro</a> cut off diplomatic relations with Colombia after Colombian President Ivan Duque had helped Venezuelan opposition politicians deliver humanitarian aid to their country. Colombia recognized Venezuelan opposition leader <a href="/wiki/Juan_Guaid%C3%B3" title="Juan Guaidó">Juan Guaidó</a> as the country's legitimate president. In January 2020, Colombia rejected Maduro's proposal that the two countries would restore diplomatic relations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[142]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/2021_Colombian_protests" title="2021 Colombian protests">Protests</a> started on 28 April 2021 when the government proposed a tax bill which would greatly expand the range of the 19 percent <a href="/wiki/Value-added_tax" title="Value-added tax">value-added tax</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyb220721_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyb220721-150">[143]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 19 June 2022 <a href="/wiki/2022_Colombian_presidential_election" title="2022 Colombian presidential election">election</a> run-off vote ended in a win for former guerrilla, <a href="/wiki/Gustavo_Petro" title="Gustavo Petro">Gustavo Petro</a>, taking 50.47% of the vote compared to 47.27% for independent candidate <a href="/wiki/Rodolfo_Hern%C3%A1ndez_Su%C3%A1rez" title="Rodolfo Hernández Suárez">Rodolfo Hernández</a>. The single-term limit for the country's presidency prevented president Iván Duque from seeking re-election. On 7 August 2022, Petro was sworn in, becoming the country’s first leftist president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[144]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[145]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Colombia" title="Geography of Colombia">Geography of Colombia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_Colombia" title="Geology of Colombia">Geology of Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Colombia" title="List of national parks of Colombia">List of national parks of Colombia</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_in_Colombia" title="List of rivers in Colombia">List of rivers in Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mapa_de_Colombia_(topograf%C3%ADa).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1896" data-file-width="1420" decoding="async" height="307" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28topograf%C3%ADa%29.svg/230px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28topograf%C3%ADa%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28topograf%C3%ADa%29.svg/345px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28topograf%C3%ADa%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28topograf%C3%ADa%29.svg/460px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28topograf%C3%ADa%29.svg.png 2x" width="230"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mapa_de_Colombia_(topograf%C3%ADa).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Relief map</div></div></div>
<p>The geography of Colombia is characterized by its six main <a href="/wiki/Natural_regions_of_Colombia" title="Natural regions of Colombia">natural regions</a> that present their own unique characteristics, from the <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">Andes</a> mountain range region shared with Ecuador and Venezuela; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacific_Coast" title="Pacific Coast">Pacific Coastal</a> region shared with Panama and Ecuador; the Caribbean coastal region shared with Venezuela and Panama; the <i><a href="/wiki/Llanos" title="Llanos">Llanos</a></i> (plains) shared with Venezuela; the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">Amazon rainforest</a> region shared with Venezuela, Brazil, Peru and Ecuador; to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Insular_Region_(Colombia)" title="Insular Region (Colombia)">insular area</a>, comprising islands in both the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geography_of_Colombia_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-Geography_of_Colombia-153">[146]</a></sup> It shares its maritime limits with <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">Costa Rica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nicaragua" title="Nicaragua">Nicaragua</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honduras" title="Honduras">Honduras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica">Jamaica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">Haiti</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">Dominican Republic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maritime_borders_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-Maritime_borders-154">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>Colombia is bordered to the northwest by <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a>, to the east by <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> and Brazil, and to the south by <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Land_borders_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-Land_borders-155">[148]</a></sup> it established its maritime boundaries with neighboring countries through seven agreements on the Caribbean Sea and three on the Pacific Ocean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maritime_borders_154-1"><a href="#cite_note-Maritime_borders-154">[147]</a></sup> It lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/12th_parallel_north" title="12th parallel north">12°N</a> and <a href="/wiki/4th_parallel_south" title="4th parallel south">4°S</a> and between longitudes <a href="/wiki/67th_meridian_west" title="67th meridian west">67°</a> and <a href="/wiki/79th_meridian_west" title="79th meridian west">79°W</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_COL_present.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="850" data-file-width="1263" decoding="async" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Koppen-Geiger_Map_COL_present.svg/290px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_COL_present.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Koppen-Geiger_Map_COL_present.svg/435px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_COL_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Koppen-Geiger_Map_COL_present.svg/580px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_COL_present.svg.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_COL_present.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Colombia map of <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a></div></div></div>
<p>Part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacific_Ring_of_Fire" title="Pacific Ring of Fire">Ring of Fire</a>, a region of the world subject to earthquakes and <a href="/wiki/Volcano" title="Volcano">volcanic eruptions</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ring_of_Fire_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ring_of_Fire-156">[149]</a></sup> in the interior of Colombia the Andes are the prevailing geographical feature. Most of Colombia's population centers are located in these interior highlands.
