Beyond the <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Massif" title="Colombian Massif">Colombian Massif</a> (in the southwestern departments of <a href="/wiki/Cauca_Department" title="Cauca Department">Cauca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nari%C3%B1o_Department" title="Nariño Department">Nariño</a>), these are divided into three branches known as <i>cordilleras</i> (mountain ranges): the <a href="/wiki/Cordillera_Occidental_(Colombia)" title="Cordillera Occidental (Colombia)">Cordillera Occidental</a>, running adjacent to the Pacific coast and including the city of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santiago_de_Cali" title="Santiago de Cali">Cali</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Cordillera_Central_(Colombia)" title="Cordillera Central (Colombia)">Cordillera Central</a>, running between the <a href="/wiki/Cauca_River" title="Cauca River">Cauca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Magdalena_River" title="Magdalena River">Magdalena River</a> valleys (to the west and east, respectively) and including the cities of <a href="/wiki/Medell%C3%ADn" title="Medellín">Medellín</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manizales" title="Manizales">Manizales</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pereira,_Colombia" title="Pereira, Colombia">Pereira</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Armenia,_Quind%C3%ADo" title="Armenia, Quindío">Armenia</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Cordillera_Oriental_(Colombia)" title="Cordillera Oriental (Colombia)">Cordillera Oriental</a>, extending northeast to the <a href="/wiki/Guajira_Peninsula" title="Guajira Peninsula">Guajira Peninsula</a> and including Bogotá, <a href="/wiki/Bucaramanga" title="Bucaramanga">Bucaramanga</a>, and <a href="/wiki/C%C3%BAcuta" title="Cúcuta">Cúcuta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geography_of_Colombia_153-1"><a href="#cite_note-Geography_of_Colombia-153">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-populationbyregions_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-populationbyregions-157">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Population_density_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-Population_density-158">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Peaks in the Cordillera Occidental exceed 4,700 m (15,420 ft), and in the Cordillera Central and Cordillera Oriental they reach 5,000 m (16,404 ft). At 2,600 m (8,530 ft), Bogotá is the highest city of its size in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geography_of_Colombia_153-2"><a href="#cite_note-Geography_of_Colombia-153">[146]</a></sup>
</p><p>East of the Andes lies the <a href="/wiki/Savanna" title="Savanna">savanna</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Llanos" title="Llanos">Llanos</a></i>, part of the <a href="/wiki/Orinoco" title="Orinoco">Orinoco</a> River basin, and in the far southeast, the <a href="/wiki/Jungle" title="Jungle">jungle</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest">Amazon rainforest</a>. Together these lowlands make up over half Colombia's territory, but they contain less than 6% of the population. To the north the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caribbean_Region_of_Colombia" title="Caribbean Region of Colombia">Caribbean coast</a>, home to 21.9% of the population and the location of the major port cities of <a href="/wiki/Barranquilla" title="Barranquilla">Barranquilla</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">Cartagena</a>, generally consists of low-lying plains, but it also contains the <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_de_Santa_Marta" title="Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta">Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta</a> mountain range, which includes the country's tallest peaks (<a href="/wiki/Pico_Crist%C3%B3bal_Col%C3%B3n" title="Pico Cristóbal Colón">Pico Cristóbal Colón</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pico_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar" title="Pico Simón Bolívar">Pico Simón Bolívar</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/La_Guajira_Desert" title="La Guajira Desert">La Guajira Desert</a>. By contrast the narrow and discontinuous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacific_Region_of_Colombia" title="Pacific Region of Colombia">Pacific coastal lowlands</a>, backed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baud%C3%B3_Mountains" title="Baudó Mountains">Serranía de Baudó</a> mountains, are sparsely populated and covered in dense vegetation. The principal Pacific port is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buenaventura,_Colombia" title="Buenaventura, Colombia">Buenaventura</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geography_of_Colombia_153-3"><a href="#cite_note-Geography_of_Colombia-153">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-populationbyregions_157-1"><a href="#cite_note-populationbyregions-157">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Population_density_158-1"><a href="#cite_note-Population_density-158">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>The main rivers of Colombia are Magdalena, Cauca, <a href="/wiki/Guaviare_River" title="Guaviare River">Guaviare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Atrato_River" title="Atrato River">Atrato</a>, <a href="/wiki/Meta_River" title="Meta River">Meta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Putumayo_River" title="Putumayo River">Putumayo</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caquet%C3%A1_River" title="Caquetá River">Caquetá</a>. Colombia has four main drainage systems: the Pacific drain, the Caribbean drain, the Orinoco Basin and the Amazon Basin. The Orinoco and <a href="/wiki/Amazon_River" title="Amazon River">Amazon</a> Rivers mark limits with Colombia to Venezuela and Peru respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hydrography_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hydrography-159">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>Protected areas and the "National Park System" cover an area of about 14,268,224 hectares (142,682.24 km<sup>2</sup>) and account for 12.77% of the Colombian territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[153]</a></sup> Compared to neighboring countries, rates of <a href="/wiki/Deforestation_in_Colombia" title="Deforestation in Colombia">deforestation in Colombia</a> are still relatively low.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-United_Nations_Deforestation_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-United_Nations_Deforestation-161">[154]</a></sup> Colombia had a 2018 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 8.26/10, ranking it 25th globally out of 172 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-162">[155]</a></sup> Colombia is the sixth country in the world by magnitude of total renewable freshwater supply, and still has large reserves of freshwater.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldwater_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-worldwater-163">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Colombia" title="Climate of Colombia">Climate of Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nevado_del_tolima_y_sus_frailejones.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Nevado_del_tolima_y_sus_frailejones.jpg/220px-Nevado_del_tolima_y_sus_frailejones.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Nevado_del_tolima_y_sus_frailejones.jpg/330px-Nevado_del_tolima_y_sus_frailejones.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Nevado_del_tolima_y_sus_frailejones.jpg/440px-Nevado_del_tolima_y_sus_frailejones.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nevado_del_tolima_y_sus_frailejones.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mountain climate is one of the unique features of the Andes and other high altitude reliefs</div></div></div>
<p>The climate of Colombia is characterized for being tropical presenting variations within <a href="/wiki/Natural_regions_of_Colombia" title="Natural regions of Colombia">six natural regions</a> and depending on the altitude, temperature, <a href="/wiki/Humidity" title="Humidity">humidity</a>, winds and rainfall.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thermal_floors_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-Thermal_floors-164">[157]</a></sup> Colombia has a diverse range of climate zones, including <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest" title="Tropical rainforest">tropical rainforests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Savanna" title="Savanna">savannas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Desert" title="Desert">deserts</a> and mountain climates.
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mountain_climate" title="Mountain climate">Mountain climate</a> is one of the unique features of the Andes and other high altitude reliefs where climate is determined by elevation. Below 1,000 meters (3,281 ft) in elevation is the <a href="/wiki/Tierra_caliente" title="Tierra caliente">warm altitudinal zone</a>, where temperatures are above 24 °C (75.2 °F). About 82.5% of the country's total area lies in the warm altitudinal zone. The <a href="/wiki/Tierra_templada" title="Tierra templada">temperate climate altitudinal zone</a> located between 1,001 and 2,000 meters (3,284 and 6,562 ft) is characterized for presenting an average temperature ranging between 17 and 24 °C (62.6 and 75.2 °F). The <a href="/wiki/Tierra_fr%C3%ADa" title="Tierra fría">cold climate</a> is present between 2,001 and 3,000 meters (6,565 and 9,843 ft) and the temperatures vary between 12 and 17 °C (53.6 and 62.6 °F). Beyond lies the alpine conditions of the forested zone and then the treeless grasslands of the <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A1ramo" title="Páramo">páramos</a>. Above 4,000 meters (13,123 ft), where temperatures are below freezing, the climate is <a href="/wiki/Tierra_helada" title="Tierra helada">glacial</a>, a zone of permanent snow and ice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thermal_floors_164-1"><a href="#cite_note-Thermal_floors-164">[157]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_of_Colombia" title="Biodiversity of Colombia">Biodiversity of Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Colombia" title="Fauna of Colombia">Fauna of Colombia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Flora_of_Colombia" title="Flora of Colombia">Flora of Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2400" data-file-width="3200" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg/220px-Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg/330px-Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg/440px-Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The national flower of Colombia, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endemic" title="Endemic">endemic</a> <a href="/wiki/Orchid" title="Orchid">orchid</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Cattleya_trianae" title="Cattleya trianae">Cattleya trianae</a></i>, is named for Colombian botanist and physician <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Jer%C3%B3nimo_Triana" title="José Jerónimo Triana">José Jerónimo Triana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[158]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Colombia is one of the <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse countries</a> in <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[159]</a></sup> ranking first in <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Colombia" title="List of birds of Colombia">bird species</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bird_Species_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bird_Species-167">[160]</a></sup> As for plants, the country has between 40,000 and 45,000 plant <a href="/wiki/Species" title="Species">species</a>, equivalent to 10 or 20% of total global species, which is even more remarkable given that Colombia is considered a country of intermediate size.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[161]</a></sup> Colombia is the second most biodiverse country in the world, lagging only after Brazil which is approximately 7 times bigger.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Biodiversity_of_Colombia_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-Biodiversity_of_Colombia-17">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>Colombia is the country with the planet's highest biodiversity, having the highest rate of species by area as well as the largest number of <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemisms</a> (species that are not found naturally anywhere else) of any country. About 10% of the species of the Earth live in Colombia, including over 1,900 species of bird, more than in Europe and North America combined. Colombia has 10% of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_Colombia" title="List of mammals of Colombia">mammals</a> species, 14% of the <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibian</a> species and 18% of the <a href="/wiki/Endemic_birds_of_Colombia" title="Endemic birds of Colombia">bird</a> species of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DIVERSITY_OF_SPECIES_IN_COLOMBIA_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-DIVERSITY_OF_SPECIES_IN_COLOMBIA-169">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>Colombia has about 2,000 species of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marine_fish" title="Marine fish">marine fish</a> and is the second most diverse country in <a href="/wiki/Freshwater_fish" title="Freshwater fish">freshwater fish</a>. It is also the country with the most endemic species of <a href="/wiki/List_of_butterflies_of_Colombia" title="List of butterflies of Colombia">butterflies</a>, is first in <a href="/wiki/Orchid" title="Orchid">orchid</a> species, and has approximately 7,000 species of <a href="/wiki/Beetle" title="Beetle">beetles</a>. Colombia is second in the number of amphibian species and is the third most diverse country in <a href="/wiki/List_of_reptiles_of_Colombia" title="List of reptiles of Colombia">reptiles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arecaceae" title="Arecaceae">palms</a>. There are about 1,900 species of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mollusk" title="Mollusk">mollusks</a> and according to estimates there are about 300,000 species of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Invertebrates" title="Invertebrates">invertebrates</a> in the country. In Colombia there are 32 terrestrial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biomes" title="Biomes">biomes</a> and 314 types of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ecosystems" title="Ecosystems">ecosystems</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[163]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-humboldt_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-humboldt-171">[164]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Colombia" title="Government of Colombia">Government of Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Constitution_of_1991" title="Colombian Constitution of 1991">Colombian Constitution of 1991</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="539" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg/250px-Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg/375px-Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg/500px-Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o" title="Casa de Nariño">Casa de Nariño</a> is the official home and principal workplace of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Colombia" title="President of Colombia">President of Colombia</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The government of Colombia takes place within the framework of a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential</a> <a href="/wiki/Participatory_democracy" title="Participatory democracy">participatory democratic</a> republic as established in the Constitution of 1991.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_Constitution_of_1991_127-1"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_Constitution_of_1991-127">[120]</a></sup> In accordance with the principle of <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">separation of powers</a>, government is divided into three branches: the executive branch, the legislative branch and the judicial branch.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>As the head of the executive branch, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Colombia" title="President of Colombia">President of Colombia</a> serves as both <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_Colombia" title="Vice President of Colombia">Vice President</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_the_Republic_of_Colombia" title="Council of Ministers of the Republic of Colombia">Council of Ministers</a>. The president is elected by popular vote to serve a single four-year term (In 2015, Colombia's Congress approved the repeal of a 2004 constitutional amendment that changed the one-term limit for presidents to a two-term limit).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[166]</a></sup> At the provincial level executive power is vested in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Colombian_Department_Governors" title="List of Colombian Department Governors">department governors</a>, <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Colombia" title="Municipalities of Colombia">municipal mayors</a> and local administrators for smaller administrative subdivisions, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Corregimientos_of_Colombia" title="Corregimientos of Colombia">corregimientos</a></i> or <i>comunas</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[167]</a></sup> All regional elections are held one year and five months after the presidential election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Government_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-Government-175">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[169]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:El_Capitolio_Nacional_(Bogot%C3%A1,_Colombia)_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1832" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/El_Capitolio_Nacional_%28Bogot%C3%A1%2C_Colombia%29_1.jpg/250px-El_Capitolio_Nacional_%28Bogot%C3%A1%2C_Colombia%29_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/El_Capitolio_Nacional_%28Bogot%C3%A1%2C_Colombia%29_1.jpg/375px-El_Capitolio_Nacional_%28Bogot%C3%A1%2C_Colombia%29_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/El_Capitolio_Nacional_%28Bogot%C3%A1%2C_Colombia%29_1.jpg/500px-El_Capitolio_Nacional_%28Bogot%C3%A1%2C_Colombia%29_1.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:El_Capitolio_Nacional_(Bogot%C3%A1,_Colombia)_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Capitolio_Nacional" title="Capitolio Nacional">Capitolio Nacional</a> seat of the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Colombia" title="Congress of Colombia">Congress</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The legislative branch of government is represented nationally by the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Colombia" title="Congress of Colombia">Congress</a>, a bicameral institution comprising a 166-seat <a href="/wiki/Chamber_of_Representatives_of_Colombia" title="Chamber of Representatives of Colombia">Chamber of Representatives</a> and a 102-seat <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Colombia" title="Senate of Colombia">Senate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[171]</a></sup> The Senate is elected nationally and the Chamber of Representatives is elected in electoral districts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[172]</a></sup> Members of both houses are elected to serve four-year terms two months before the president, also by popular vote.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>The judicial branch is headed by <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Colombia" title="Judiciary of Colombia">four high courts</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[174]</a></sup> consisting of the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Justice_of_Colombia" title="Supreme Court of Justice of Colombia">Supreme Court</a> which deals with penal and civil matters, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_State_of_Colombia" title="Council of State of Colombia">Council of State</a>, which has special responsibility for <a href="/wiki/Administrative_law" title="Administrative law">administrative law</a> and also provides legal advice to the executive, the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Colombia" title="Constitutional Court of Colombia">Constitutional Court</a>, responsible for assuring the integrity of the Colombian constitution, and the <a href="/wiki/Superior_Council_of_Judicature" title="Superior Council of Judicature">Superior Council of Judicature</a>, responsible for auditing the judicial branch.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[175]</a></sup> Colombia operates a system of <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a>, which since 2005 has been applied through an <a href="/wiki/Adversarial_system" title="Adversarial system">adversarial system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[176]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Despite a number of controversies, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Democratic_security_policy" title="Democratic security policy">democratic security policy</a> has ensured that former President <a href="/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Uribe" title="Álvaro Uribe">Álvaro Uribe</a> remained popular among Colombian people, with his approval rating peaking at 76%, according to a poll in 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[177]</a></sup> However, having served two terms, he was constitutionally barred from seeking re-election in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[178]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the run-off <a href="/wiki/2010_Colombian_presidential_election" title="2010 Colombian presidential election">elections</a> on 20 June 2010 the former Minister of Defense <a href="/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Santos" title="Juan Manuel Santos">Juan Manuel Santos</a> won with 69% of the vote against the second most popular candidate, <a href="/wiki/Antanas_Mockus" title="Antanas Mockus">Antanas Mockus</a>. A second round was required since no candidate received over the 50% winning threshold of votes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[179]</a></sup> Santos won re-election with nearly 51% of the vote in second-round <a href="/wiki/2014_Colombian_presidential_election" title="2014 Colombian presidential election">elections</a> on 15 June 2014, beating right-wing rival <a href="/wiki/%C3%93scar_Iv%C3%A1n_Zuluaga" title="Óscar Iván Zuluaga">Óscar Iván Zuluaga</a>, who won 45%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2018, <a href="/wiki/Iv%C3%A1n_Duque" title="Iván Duque">Iván Duque</a> won in the second round of the <a href="/wiki/2018_Colombian_presidential_election" title="2018 Colombian presidential election">election</a> with 54% of the vote, against 42% for his left-wing rival, <a href="/wiki/Gustavo_Petro" title="Gustavo Petro">Gustavo Petro</a>. His term as Colombia's president ran for four years, beginning on 7 August 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[181]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2022, Colombia <a href="/wiki/2022_Colombian_presidential_election" title="2022 Colombian presidential election">elected</a> Gustavo Petro, who became its first leftist leader,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[182]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Francia_Marquez" title="Francia Marquez">Francia Marquez</a>, who was the first black person elected as Vice President.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[183]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_affairs">Foreign affairs</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Colombia" title="Foreign relations of Colombia">Foreign relations of Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diplomatic_missions_of_Colombia" title="Diplomatic missions of Colombia">Diplomatic missions of Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:VII_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico,_Santiago_de_Cali.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1214" data-file-width="2031" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/VII_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico%2C_Santiago_de_Cali.jpg/220px-VII_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico%2C_Santiago_de_Cali.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/VII_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico%2C_Santiago_de_Cali.jpg/330px-VII_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico%2C_Santiago_de_Cali.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/VII_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico%2C_Santiago_de_Cali.jpg/440px-VII_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico%2C_Santiago_de_Cali.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:VII_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico,_Santiago_de_Cali.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The VII Summit of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Alliance" title="Pacific Alliance">Pacific Alliance</a>: Former President of Colombia, <a href="/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Santos" title="Juan Manuel Santos">Juan Manuel Santos</a> is second from the left.</div></div></div>
<p>The foreign affairs of Colombia are headed by the President, as head of state, and managed by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Colombia)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Colombia)">Minister of Foreign Affairs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_foreign_affairs_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_foreign_affairs-191">[184]</a></sup> Colombia has diplomatic missions in all continents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>Colombia was one of the four founding members of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Alliance" title="Pacific Alliance">Pacific Alliance</a>, which is a political, economic and co-operative integration mechanism that promotes the free circulation of goods, services, capital and persons between the members, as well as a common stock exchange and joint embassies in several countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Pacific_Alliance_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pacific_Alliance-193">[186]</a></sup> Colombia is also a member of the United Nations, the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">Organization of Ibero-American States</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Andean_Community_of_Nations" title="Andean Community of Nations">Andean Community of Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[189]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[191]</a></sup> Colombia is a global partner of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[192]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_Colombia" title="Military of Colombia">Military of Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_(S-70A-41)_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1333" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_%28S-70A-41%29_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg/220px-Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_%28S-70A-41%29_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_%28S-70A-41%29_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg/330px-Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_%28S-70A-41%29_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_%28S-70A-41%29_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg/440px-Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_%28S-70A-41%29_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_(S-70A-41)_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sikorsky_UH-60_Black_Hawk" title="Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk">Arpía III</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Air_Force" title="Colombian Air Force">Colombian Air Force</a></div></div></div>
<p>The executive branch of government is responsible for managing the defense of Colombia, with the President <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the armed forces. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defence_(Colombia)" title="Ministry of National Defence (Colombia)">Ministry of Defence</a> exercises day-to-day control of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_Colombia" title="Military of Colombia">military</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_National_Police" title="Colombian National Police">Colombian National Police</a>. Colombia has 455,461 active military personnel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[193]</a></sup> In 2016, 3.4% of the country's GDP went towards military expenditure, placing it 24th in the world. Colombia's armed forces are the largest in Latin America, and it is the second largest spender on its military after Brazil.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[195]</a></sup> In 2018, Colombia signed the UN <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Prohibition_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons">treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Colombian military is divided into three branches: the <a href="/wiki/National_Army_of_Colombia" title="National Army of Colombia">National Army of Colombia</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Air_Force" title="Colombian Air Force">Colombian Air Force</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Navy" title="Colombian Navy">Colombian Navy</a>. The National Police functions as a <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie" title="Gendarmerie">gendarmerie</a>, operating independently from the military as the law enforcement agency for the entire country. Each of these operates with their own intelligence apparatus separate from the <a href="/wiki/National_Intelligence_Directorate_(Colombia)" title="National Intelligence Directorate (Colombia)">National Intelligence Directorate</a> (DNI, in Spanish).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Colombian_military_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Colombian_military-204">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p>The National Army is formed by divisions, brigades, special brigades, and special units,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_National_Army_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_National_Army-205">[198]</a></sup> the Colombian Navy by the <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Naval_Infantry" title="Colombian Naval Infantry">Naval Infantry</a>, the Naval Force of the Caribbean, the Naval Force of the Pacific, the Naval Force of the South, the Naval Force of the East, Colombia Coast Guards, Naval Aviation, and the Specific Command of San Andres y Providencia<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-the_National_Armada_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-the_National_Armada-206">[199]</a></sup> and the Air Force by 15 air units.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Air_Force_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Air_Force-207">[200]</a></sup> The National Police has a presence in all municipalities.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement_and_crime">Law enforcement and crime</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/National_Police_of_Colombia" title="National Police of Colombia">National Police of Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Colombia" title="Crime in Colombia">Crime in Colombia</a></div>
<p>Colombia has a very high crime rate due to being a center for the cultivation and trafficking of <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a>. The <a href="/wiki/National_Police_of_Colombia" title="National Police of Colombia">national police</a> force of Colombia are the <a href="/wiki/National_Police_of_Colombia" title="National Police of Colombia">National Police of Colombia</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Departments_of_Colombia" title="Departments of Colombia">Departments of Colombia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Colombia" title="Municipalities of Colombia">Municipalities of Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Colombia" title="List of cities in Colombia">List of cities in Colombia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Corregimientos_of_Colombia" title="Corregimientos of Colombia">Corregimientos of Colombia</a></div>
<p>Colombia is divided into 32 <a href="/wiki/Departments_of_Colombia" title="Departments of Colombia">departments</a> and one <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">capital district</a>, which is treated as a department (Bogotá also serves as the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Cundinamarca_Department" title="Cundinamarca Department">department of Cundinamarca</a>). Departments are subdivided into <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Colombia" title="Municipalities of Colombia">municipalities</a>, each of which is assigned a municipal seat, and municipalities are in turn subdivided into <i><a href="/wiki/Corregimientos_of_Colombia" title="Corregimientos of Colombia">corregimientos</a></i> in rural areas and into <i><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Comunas_of_Colombia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Comunas of Colombia (page does not exist)">comunas</a></i> in urban areas. Each department has a local government with a governor and assembly directly elected to four-year terms, and each municipality is headed by a mayor and council. There is a popularly elected local administrative board in each of the <i>corregimientos</i> or <i>comunas</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Administrative_divisions_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-Administrative_divisions-208">[201]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Concerning_the_territorial_organization_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-Concerning_the_territorial_organization-209">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to the capital, four other cities have been designated <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Colombia" title="Districts of Colombia">districts</a> (in effect special municipalities), on the basis of special distinguishing features. These are <a href="/wiki/Barranquilla" title="Barranquilla">Barranquilla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">Cartagena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santa_Marta" title="Santa Marta">Santa Marta</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buenaventura,_Colombia" title="Buenaventura, Colombia">Buenaventura</a>. Some departments have local administrative subdivisions, where towns have a large concentration of population and municipalities are near each other (for example, in Antioquia and Cundinamarca). Where departments have a low population (for example Amazonas, Vaupés and Vichada), special administrative divisions are employed, such as "department <i>corregimientos</i>", which are a hybrid of a municipality and a <i>corregimiento</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Administrative_divisions_208-1"><a href="#cite_note-Administrative_divisions-208">[201]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Concerning_the_territorial_organization_209-1"><a href="#cite_note-Concerning_the_territorial_organization-209">[202]</a></sup>
</p><p><small>Click on a department on the map below to go to its article.</small>
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Largest_cities_and_towns">Largest cities and towns</span></h3>
<p>Colombia is a highly urbanized country with 77.1% of the population living in urban areas. The largest cities in the country are <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">Bogotá</a>, with 7,387,400 inhabitants, <a href="/wiki/Medell%C3%ADn" title="Medellín">Medellín</a>, with 2,382,399 inhabitants, <a href="/wiki/Cali" title="Cali">Cali</a>, with 2,172,527 inhabitants, and <a href="/wiki/Barranquilla" title="Barranquilla">Barranquilla</a>, with 1,205,284 inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[205]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>
<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray; background: #f9f9f9">
<tbody><tr>
<th colspan="10" style="padding:0.3em 0.75em;"><div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em"> </div><div style="float:left; width:6em; height:2.6em"> </div> <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;"><span style="font-size:110%;">Largest cities or towns in Colombia</span><br/><div style="display:inline;font-weight:normal;">According to the 2018 Census<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[206]</a></sup></div></div>
</th></tr>
<tr>
