</tbody></table></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Colombia" title="Economy of Colombia">Economy of Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Colombia" title="Agriculture in Colombia">Agriculture in Colombia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Industry_of_Colombia" title="Industry of Colombia">Industry of Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Colombia_GDP_by_sector_in_2017.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="444" data-file-width="635" decoding="async" height="280" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Colombia_GDP_by_sector_in_2017.png/400px-Colombia_GDP_by_sector_in_2017.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Colombia_GDP_by_sector_in_2017.png/600px-Colombia_GDP_by_sector_in_2017.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e2/Colombia_GDP_by_sector_in_2017.png 2x" width="400"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Colombia_GDP_by_sector_in_2017.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Colombia GDP by sector in 2017.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GDP_per_capita_development_in_Colombia.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="850" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/GDP_per_capita_development_in_Colombia.svg/220px-GDP_per_capita_development_in_Colombia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/GDP_per_capita_development_in_Colombia.svg/330px-GDP_per_capita_development_in_Colombia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/GDP_per_capita_development_in_Colombia.svg/440px-GDP_per_capita_development_in_Colombia.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GDP_per_capita_development_in_Colombia.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Historical GDP per capita development</div></div></div>
<p>Historically an agrarian economy, Colombia urbanized rapidly in the 20th century, by the end of which just 15.8% of the workforce were employed in agriculture, generating just 6.6% of GDP; 19.6% of the workforce were employed in industry and 64.6% in services, responsible for 33.4% and 59.9% of GDP respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDP_Composition_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-GDP_Composition-214">[207]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[208]</a></sup> The country's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Economic_production" title="Economic production">economic production</a> is dominated by its strong <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Domestic_demand" title="Domestic demand">domestic demand</a>. <a href="/wiki/Consumer_spending" title="Consumer spending">Consumption expenditure</a> by households is the largest component of GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDPCOLOMBIA_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-GDPCOLOMBIA-216">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDP_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-GDP-19">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombianeconomy_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombianeconomy-217">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>Colombia's <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a> grew steadily in the latter part of the 20th century, with gross domestic product (GDP) increasing at an average rate of over 4% per year between 1970 and 1998. The country suffered a <a href="/wiki/Recession" title="Recession">recession</a> in 1999 (the first full year of negative growth since the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a>), and the recovery from that recession was long and painful. However, in recent years growth has been impressive, reaching 6.9% in 2007, one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(real)_growth_rate" title="List of countries by GDP (real) growth rate">highest rates of growth</a> in Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombia's_GDP_growth_16-1"><a href="#cite_note-Colombia's_GDP_growth-16">[14]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> estimates, in 2012, Colombia's GDP (PPP) was US$500 billion (<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">28th in the world</a> and third in South America).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Total <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government_expenditures" title="Government expenditures">government expenditures</a> account for 27.9 percent of the domestic economy. <a href="/wiki/External_debt" title="External debt">External debt</a> equals 39.9 percent of gross domestic product. A strong fiscal climate was reaffirmed by a boost in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bond_ratings" title="Bond ratings">bond ratings</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[212]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-heritage_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-heritage-220">[213]</a></sup> Annual inflation closed 2017 at 4.09% YoY (vs. 5.75% YoY in 2016).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Inflation_Rate_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-Inflation_Rate-221">[214]</a></sup> The average national <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unemployment_rate" title="Unemployment rate">unemployment rate</a> in 2017 was 9.4%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unemployment_Rate_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-Unemployment_Rate-222">[215]</a></sup> although the informality is the biggest problem facing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labour_market" title="Labour market">labour market</a> (the income of formal workers climbed 24.8% in 5 years while labor incomes of informal workers rose only 9%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-informal_workers_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-informal_workers-223">[216]</a></sup> Colombia has <a href="/wiki/Free-trade_zone" title="Free-trade zone">free-trade zones</a> (FTZ),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FTZ_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-FTZ-224">[217]</a></sup> such as Zona Franca del Pacifico, located in the <a href="/wiki/Valle_del_Cauca_Department" title="Valle del Cauca Department">Valle del Cauca</a>, one of the most striking areas for foreign investment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zonas_Francas_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zonas_Francas-225">[218]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_sector" title="Financial sector">financial sector</a> has grown favorably due to good liquidity in the economy, the growth of credit and the positive performance of the Colombian economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-strongmacroeconomicmanagement_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-strongmacroeconomicmanagement-20">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[219]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[220]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_Stock_Exchange" title="Colombian Stock Exchange">Colombian Stock Exchange</a> through the Latin American Integrated Market (<a href="/wiki/Mercado_Integrado_Latinoamericano" title="Mercado Integrado Latinoamericano">MILA</a>) offers a regional market to trade equities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[222]</a></sup> Colombia is now one of only three economies with a perfect score on the strength of legal rights index, according to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[223]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BVC_Bogota.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1460" data-file-width="928" decoding="async" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/BVC_Bogota.jpg/150px-BVC_Bogota.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/BVC_Bogota.jpg/225px-BVC_Bogota.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/BVC_Bogota.jpg/300px-BVC_Bogota.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BVC_Bogota.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_Stock_Exchange" title="Colombian Stock Exchange">Colombian Stock Exchange</a> is part of the Latin American Integrated Market (<a href="/wiki/Mercado_Integrado_Latinoamericano" title="Mercado Integrado Latinoamericano">MILA</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MILA_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-MILA-231">[224]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Colombia is rich in natural resources, and it is heavily dependent on energy and mining exports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[225]</a></sup> Colombia's main exports include mineral fuels, oils, <a href="/wiki/Distillation#Industrial_distillation" title="Distillation">distillation products</a>, fruit and other agricultural products, sugars and sugar confectionery, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Food_products" title="Food products">food products</a>, plastics, precious stones, metals, forest products, <a href="/wiki/Chemical_industry" title="Chemical industry">chemical goods</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pharmaceuticals" title="Pharmaceuticals">pharmaceuticals</a>, vehicles, electronic products, electrical equipment, perfumery and cosmetics, machinery, manufactured articles, textile and fabrics, clothing and footwear, glass and glassware, furniture, prefabricated buildings, military products, home and office material, construction equipment, software, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ITC_Colombia_Exports_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-ITC_Colombia_Exports-233">[226]</a></sup> Principal trading partners are the United States, China, the European Union and some Latin American countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Exports_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-Exports-234">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Imports_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-Imports-235">[228]</a></sup>
</p><p>Non-traditional exports have boosted the growth of Colombian foreign sales as well as the diversification of destinations of export thanks to new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_trade_agreements" title="Free trade agreements">free trade agreements</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[229]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2017, the National Administrative Department of Statistics (DANE) reported that 26.9% of the population were living below the poverty line, of which 7.4% were in "extreme poverty". The multidimensional poverty rate stands at 17.0 percent of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-socio-economic_policies_6-1"><a href="#cite_note-socio-economic_policies-6">[6]</a></sup> The Government has also been developing a process of <a href="/wiki/Financial_inclusion" title="Financial inclusion">financial inclusion</a> within the country's most vulnerable population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[230]</a></sup>
</p><p>Recent economic growth has led to a considerable increase of new millionaires, including the new entrepreneurs, Colombians with a net worth exceeding US$1 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[231]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[232]</a></sup>
</p><p>The contribution of <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Colombia" title="Tourism in Colombia">Travel &amp; Tourism</a> to GDP was US$5,880.3bn (2.0% of total GDP) in 2016. Tourism generated 556,135 jobs (2.5% of total employment) in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[233]</a></sup> Foreign tourist visits were predicted to have risen from 0.6 million in 2007 to 4 million in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[235]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture_and_livestock">Agriculture and livestock</span></h3>
<p>In agriculture, Colombia is one of the 5 largest producers in the world of <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Avocado" title="Avocado">avocado</a> and <a href="/wiki/Palm_oil" title="Palm oil">palm oil</a>, and one of the 10 largest producers in the world of <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banana" title="Banana">banana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pineapple" title="Pineapple">pineapple</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">cocoa</a>. The country also has considerable production of <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">potato</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cassava" title="Cassava">cassava</a>. Although it is not the largest coffee producer in the world (since it is up to Brazil), the country has been able to carry out, for decades, a global marketing campaign to add value to the country's product. Colombian palm oil production is one of the most sustainable on the planet, compared to the largest existing producers. Colombia is also among the 20 largest producers in the world of <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chicken_meat" title="Chicken meat">chicken meat</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[238]</a></sup>
</p><p>Colombia is also the 2nd largest <a href="/wiki/Flower" title="Flower">flower</a> exporter in the world, after the Netherlands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[239]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Natural_resources">Natural resources</span></h3>
<p>Colombia is an important exporter of <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">coal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a> – in 2020, more than 40% of the country's exports were based on these two products.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[240]</a></sup> In 2018 it was the 5th largest coal exporter in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[241]</a></sup> In 2019, Colombia was the 20th largest petroleum producer in the world, with 791 thousand barrels/day, exporting a good part of its production – the country was the 19th largest oil exporter in the world in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[242]</a></sup> In mining, Colombia is the world's largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Emerald" title="Emerald">emerald</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[243]</a></sup> and in the production of <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a>, between 2006 and 2017, the country produced 15 tons per year until 2007, when its production increased significantly, beating the record of 66.1 tons extracted in 2012. In 2017, it extracted 52.2 tons. Currently, the country is among the 25 largest gold producers in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[244]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Colombia" title="Transport in Colombia">Transport in Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg/190px-Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg/285px-Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg/380px-Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg 2x" width="190"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Port of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cartagena_de_Indias" title="Cartagena de Indias">Cartagena</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Transportation in Colombia is regulated within the functions of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Transport_(Colombia)" title="Ministry of Transport (Colombia)">Ministry of Transport</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTransport_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-MTransport-252">[245]</a></sup> and entities such as the National Roads Institute (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/INV%C3%8DAS" title="INVÍAS">INVÍAS</a>) responsible for the <a href="/wiki/Highways_in_Colombia" title="Highways in Colombia">Highways in Colombia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[246]</a></sup> the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aerocivil" title="Aerocivil">Aerocivil</a>, responsible for civil aviation and <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Colombia" title="List of airports in Colombia">airports</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[247]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/National_Infrastructure_Agency_(Colombia)" title="National Infrastructure Agency (Colombia)">National Infrastructure Agency</a>, in charge of <a href="/wiki/Concession_(contract)" title="Concession (contract)">concessions</a> through <a href="/wiki/Public%E2%80%93private_partnership" title="Public–private partnership">public–private partnerships</a>, for the design, construction, maintenance, operation, and administration of the transport infrastructure,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[248]</a></sup> the General Maritime Directorate (Dimar) has the responsibility of coordinating maritime traffic control along with the Colombian Navy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[249]</a></sup> among others and under the supervision of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Superintendency_of_Ports_and_Transport_(Colombia)" title="Superintendency of Ports and Transport (Colombia)">Superintendency of Ports and Transport</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2021, Colombia had 204,389 km (127,001 mi) of roads, 32,280 km (20,058 mi) of which were paved. At the end of 2017, the country had around 2,100 km (1,305 mi) of <a href="/wiki/Dual_carriageway" title="Dual carriageway">duplicated highways</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[251]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transporte_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-transporte-260">[253]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Colombia" title="Rail transport in Colombia">Rail transportation</a> in Colombia is dedicated almost entirely to <a href="/wiki/Rail_freight_transport" title="Rail freight transport">freight shipments</a> and the railway network has a length of 1,700 km of potentially active rails.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transporte_260-1"><a href="#cite_note-transporte-260">[253]</a></sup> Colombia has 3,960 kilometers of gas pipelines, 4,900 kilometers of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oil_pipelines" title="Oil pipelines">oil pipelines</a>, and 2,990 kilometers of refined-products pipelines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transporte_260-2"><a href="#cite_note-transporte-260">[253]</a></sup>
</p><p>The target of Colombia's government is to build 7,000 km of roads for the 2016–2020 period and reduce travel times by 30 per cent and transport costs by 20 per cent. A toll road concession programme will comprise 40 projects, and is part of a larger strategic goal to invest nearly $50 bn in transport infrastructure, including: railway systems; making the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magdalena_river" title="Magdalena river">Magdalena river</a> navigable again; improving port facilities; as well as an expansion of <a href="/wiki/El_Dorado_International_Airport" title="El Dorado International Airport">Bogotá's airport</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[254]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The date of the event predicted near this tag has passed. (July 2021)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Colombia is a middle-income country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[255]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<p>The electricity production in Colombia comes mainly from <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">Renewable energy</a> sources. 69.93% is obtained from the <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectric generation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[256]</a></sup> Colombia's commitment to renewable energy was recognized in the 2014 <i>Global Green Economy Index (GGEI)</i>, ranking among the top 10 nations in the world in terms of greening efficiency sectors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ggei_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-ggei-264">[257]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Colombia" title="Science and technology in Colombia">Science and technology in Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CEMSA_271215_01.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/CEMSA_271215_01.JPG/200px-CEMSA_271215_01.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/CEMSA_271215_01.JPG/300px-CEMSA_271215_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/CEMSA_271215_01.JPG/400px-CEMSA_271215_01.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CEMSA_271215_01.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colciencias" title="Colciencias">Colciencias</a> is a Colombian Government agency that supports fundamental and applied research.</div></div></div>
<p>Colombia has more than 3,950 research groups in science and technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[258]</a></sup> iNNpulsa, a government body that promotes entrepreneurship and innovation in the country, provides grants to startups, in addition to other services it and institutions provide. Colombia was ranked 67th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[259]</a></sup> Co-working spaces have arisen to serve as communities for startups large and small.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-venturebeat.com_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-venturebeat.com-267">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[261]</a></sup> Organizations such as the Corporation for Biological Research (CIB) for the support of young people interested in scientific work has been successfully developed in Colombia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[262]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/International_Center_for_Tropical_Agriculture" title="International Center for Tropical Agriculture">International Center for Tropical Agriculture</a> based in Colombia investigates the increasing challenge of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_warming" title="Global warming">global warming</a> and <a href="/wiki/Food_security" title="Food security">food security</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[263]</a></sup>
</p><p>Important inventions related to medicine have been made in Colombia, such as the first <a href="/wiki/Artificial_cardiac_pacemaker" title="Artificial cardiac pacemaker">external artificial pacemaker with internal electrodes</a>, invented by the electronics engineer <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Reynolds_Pombo" title="Jorge Reynolds Pombo">Jorge Reynolds Pombo</a>, invention of great importance for those who suffer from heart failure. Also invented in Colombia were the <a href="/wiki/Microkeratome" title="Microkeratome">microkeratome</a> and keratomileusis technique, which form the fundamental basis of what now is known as <a href="/wiki/LASIK" title="LASIK">LASIK</a> (one of the most important techniques for the correction of <a href="/wiki/Refractive_error" title="Refractive error">refractive errors</a> of vision) and the <a href="/wiki/Salom%C3%B3n_Hakim#The_Invention_of_the_valve" title="Salomón Hakim">Hakim valve</a> for the treatment of <a href="/wiki/Hydrocephalus" title="Hydrocephalus">Hydrocephalus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[264]</a></sup> Colombia has begun to innovate in military technology for its army and other armies of the world; especially in the design and creation of personal ballistic protection products, military hardware, <a href="/wiki/Military_robot" title="Military robot">military robots</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bomb" title="Bomb">bombs</a>, simulators and radar.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[267]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some leading Colombian scientists are Joseph M. Tohme, researcher recognized for his work on the <a href="/wiki/Genetic_diversity" title="Genetic diversity">genetic diversity</a> of food, <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Elkin_Patarroyo" title="Manuel Elkin Patarroyo">Manuel Elkin Patarroyo</a> who is known for his groundbreaking work on <a href="/wiki/Synthetic_vaccine" title="Synthetic vaccine">synthetic vaccines</a> for <a href="/wiki/Malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a>, Francisco Lopera who discovered the "Paisa Mutation" or a type of <a href="/wiki/Early-onset_Alzheimer%27s_disease" title="Early-onset Alzheimer's disease">early-onset Alzheimer's</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Francisco_Lopera_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-Francisco_Lopera-275">[268]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rodolfo_Llin%C3%A1s" title="Rodolfo Llinás">Rodolfo Llinás</a> known for his study of the intrinsic <a href="/wiki/Neuron" title="Neuron">neurons</a> properties and the theory of a syndrome that had changed the way of understanding the functioning of the brain, Jairo Quiroga Puello recognized for his studies on the characterization of <a href="/wiki/Synthetic_substance" title="Synthetic substance">synthetic substances</a> which can be used to fight fungus, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tumor" title="Tumor">tumors</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tuberculosis" title="Tuberculosis">tuberculosis</a> and even some viruses and Ángela Restrepo who established accurate <a href="/wiki/Medical_diagnosis" title="Medical diagnosis">diagnoses</a> and treatments to combat the effects of a disease caused by the <i><a href="/wiki/Paracoccidioides_brasiliensis" title="Paracoccidioides brasiliensis">Paracoccidioides brasiliensis</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Científicos_colombianos_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-Científicos_colombianos-276">[269]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brillantes_colombianos_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-brillantes_colombianos-277">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Científicos_destacados_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-Científicos_destacados-278">[271]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Colombia" title="Demographics of Colombia">Demographics of Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Colombian_Departments_by_population" title="List of Colombian Departments by population">List of Colombian Departments by population</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Colombia_relief_demographic_map-fr.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1394" data-file-width="1082" decoding="async" height="322" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Colombia_relief_demographic_map-fr.png/250px-Colombia_relief_demographic_map-fr.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Colombia_relief_demographic_map-fr.png/375px-Colombia_relief_demographic_map-fr.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Colombia_relief_demographic_map-fr.png/500px-Colombia_relief_demographic_map-fr.png 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Colombia_relief_demographic_map-fr.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Population density of Colombia in 2007</div></div></div>
<p>With an estimated 50 million people in 2020, Colombia is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" title="List of countries by population">third-most populous country</a> in Latin America, after Brazil and Mexico.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PopulationProjections_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-PopulationProjections-279">[272]</a></sup> At the beginning of the 20th century, Colombia's population was approximately 4 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[273]</a></sup> Since the early 1970s Colombia has experienced steady declines in its fertility, mortality, and <a href="/wiki/Population_growth" title="Population growth">population growth</a> rates. The population growth rate for 2016 is estimated to be 0.9%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Population_growth_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-Population_growth-281">[274]</a></sup> About 26.8% of the population were 15 years old or younger, 65.7% were between 15 and 64 years old, and 7.4% were over 65 years old. The proportion of older persons in the total population has begun to increase substantially.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[275]</a></sup> Colombia is projected to have a population of 55.3 million by 2050.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[276]</a></sup>
</p><p>The population is concentrated in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Andean_Region_of_Colombia" title="Andean Region of Colombia">Andean highlands</a> and along the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caribbean_Region_of_Colombia" title="Caribbean Region of Colombia">Caribbean coast</a>, also the population densities are generally higher in the Andean region. The nine eastern lowland departments, comprising about 54% of Colombia's area, have less than 6% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-populationbyregions_157-2"><a href="#cite_note-populationbyregions-157">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Population_density_158-2"><a href="#cite_note-Population_density-158">[151]</a></sup> Traditionally a rural society, <a href="/wiki/Urbanization" title="Urbanization">movement to urban areas</a> was very heavy in the mid-20th century, and Colombia is now one of the most urbanized countries in Latin America. The urban population increased from 31% of the total in 1938 to nearly 60% in 1973, and by 2014 the figure stood at 76%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Country_Study_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-Country_Study-284">[277]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[278]</a></sup> The population of <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1" title="Bogotá">Bogotá</a> alone has increased from just over 300,000 in 1938 to approximately 8 million today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[279]</a></sup> In total seventy-two cities now have populations of 100,000 or more (2015). As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Colombia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> Colombia has the world's largest populations of <a href="/wiki/Internally_displaced_person" title="Internally displaced person">internally displaced persons</a> (IDPs), estimated to be up to 4.9 million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNHCR_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNHCR-287">[280]</a></sup>
</p><p>The life expectancy is 74.8 years in 2015 and infant mortality is 13.1 per thousand in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Life_expectancy_at_birth_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-Life_expectancy_at_birth-288">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-infant_mortality_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-infant_mortality-289">[282]</a></sup> In 2015, 94.58% of adults and 98.66% of youth are literate and the government spends about 4.49% of its GDP on education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNESCO_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNESCO-290">[283]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Colombia" title="Languages of Colombia">Languages of Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Spanish" title="Colombian Spanish">Colombian Spanish</a></div>
<p>More than 99.2% of Colombians speak Spanish, also called Castilian; 65 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amerindian_language" title="Amerindian language">Amerindian languages</a>, two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Creole_languages" title="Creole languages">Creole languages</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">Romani language</a> and <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Sign_Language" title="Colombian Sign Language">Colombian Sign Language</a> are also used in the country. <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> has official status in the <a href="/wiki/Archipelago_of_San_Andr%C3%A9s,_Providencia_and_Santa_Catalina" title="Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina">archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LEY47DE1993_9-1"><a href="#cite_note-LEY47DE1993-9">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lenguas_indígenas_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-lenguas_indígenas-291">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Languages_of_Colombia_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-Languages_of_Colombia-292">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MapofthelanguagesofColombia_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-MapofthelanguagesofColombia-293">[286]</a></sup>
</p><p>Including Spanish, a total of 101 languages are listed for Colombia in the <a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">Ethnologue</a> database. The specific number of spoken languages varies slightly since some authors consider as different languages what others consider to be varieties or dialects of the same language. Best estimates recorded 71 languages that are spoken in-country today – most of which belong to the <a href="/wiki/Chibchan_languages" title="Chibchan languages">Chibchan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tucanoan_languages" title="Tucanoan languages">Tucanoan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bora%E2%80%93Witoto_languages" title="Bora–Witoto languages">Bora–Witoto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guajiboan_languages" title="Guajiboan languages">Guajiboan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arawakan_languages" title="Arawakan languages">Arawakan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cariban_languages" title="Cariban languages">Cariban</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barbacoan_languages" title="Barbacoan languages">Barbacoan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Piaroa%E2%80%93Saliban_languages" title="Piaroa–Saliban languages">Saliban</a> language families. There are currently about 850,000 speakers of native languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnologue_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-ethnologue-294">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nativelanguages_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-nativelanguages-295">[288]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_Colombia" title="Race and ethnicity in Colombia">Human biological diversity and ethnicity in Colombia</a></div>
<div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px">
<div class="mw-no-invert" style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black;transform:scaleX(-1)rotate(-90deg)">

<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#008080"></div>
</div>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<p>Human biological diversity and ethnicity-<b><a href="/wiki/2018_Colombian_census" title="2018 Colombian census">2018 Census</a></b> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grupos_étnicos_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-grupos_étnicos-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#008080; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/White_Colombians" title="White Colombians">White</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mestizo_Colombians" title="Mestizo Colombians">Mestizo</a> (87.58%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFBF00; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afro-Colombian" title="Afro-Colombian">Afro-Colombian</a> (includes <a href="/wiki/Mulatto" title="Mulatto">Mixed</a>) (6.68%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#1C39BB; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">Amerindian</a> (4.31%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#008080; color:white;"> </span> Not Stated (1.35%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFBF00; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Raizal" title="Raizal">Raizal</a> (0.06%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#008080; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Palenquero" title="Palenquero">Palenquero</a> (0.02%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#808080; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romani_People" title="Romani People">Romani</a> (0.01%)</div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Colombia is ethnically diverse, its people descending from the original <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">native</a> inhabitants, Spanish colonists, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_Colombian" title="African Colombian">Africans</a> originally brought to the country as slaves, and 20th-century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_diaspora" title="European diaspora">immigrants from Europe</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Colombians" title="Arab Colombians">Middle East</a>, all contributing to a diverse cultural heritage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombia_is_ethnically_diverse_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombia_is_ethnically_diverse-296">[289]</a></sup> The demographic distribution reflects a pattern that is influenced by colonial history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[290]</a></sup> Whites live all throughout the country, mainly in urban centers and the burgeoning highland and coastal cities. The populations of the major cities also include mestizos. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mestizo_Colombian" title="Mestizo Colombian">Mestizo</a> <i>campesinos</i> (people living in rural areas) also live in the Andean highlands where some Spanish conquerors mixed with the women of Amerindian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chiefdoms" title="Chiefdoms">chiefdoms</a>. Mestizos include artisans and small tradesmen that have played a major part in the urban expansion of recent decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[291]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2018_Colombian_Census" title="2018 Colombian Census">2018 census</a> reported that the "non-ethnic population", consisting of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_Colombian" title="White Colombian">whites</a> and mestizos (those of mixed European and Amerindian ancestry), constituted 87.58% of the national population. 6.68% is of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afro-Colombian" title="Afro-Colombian">African</a> ancestry. <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">Indigenous Amerindians</a> constitute 4.31% of the population. <a href="/wiki/Raizal" title="Raizal">Raizal</a> people constitute 0.06% of the population. <a href="/wiki/Palenquero" title="Palenquero">Palenquero</a> people constitute 0.02% of the population. 0.01% of the population are <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Roma</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Federal_Research_Division" title="Federal Research Division">Federal Research Division</a> estimated that the 86% of the population that did not consider themselves part of one of the ethnic groups indicated by the 2006 census was divided into 49% Mestizo or of mixed European and Amerindian ancestry, and 37% White, mainly of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_immigration_to_Colombia" title="Spanish immigration to Colombia">Spanish</a> lineage, but there is also a large population of <a href="/wiki/Arab_Colombians" title="Arab Colombians">Middle East</a> descent; in some sectors of society there is a considerable input of <a href="/wiki/German_Colombian" title="German Colombian">German</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_Colombian" title="Italian Colombian">Italian</a> ancestry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Society_and_Its_Environment_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Society_and_Its_Environment-299">[292]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grupos_étnicos_1-2"><a href="#cite_note-grupos_étnicos-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:308px;max-width:308px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" width="150"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">People with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_Colombian" title="African Colombian">African ancestry</a> in Colombia are concentrated mostly in coastal areas.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mapa_de_Colombia_(poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005).svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="5050" data-file-width="3731" decoding="async" height="203" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg/150px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg/225px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg/300px-Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg.png 2x" width="150"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">Amerindian</a> population of Colombia by municipality in 2005.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Many of the <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia" title="Indigenous peoples in Colombia">Indigenous peoples</a> experienced a reduction in population during the Spanish rule<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[293]</a></sup> and many others were absorbed into the mestizo population, but the remainder currently represents over eighty distinct cultures. Reserves (<i>resguardos</i>) established for indigenous peoples occupy 30,571,640 hectares (305,716.4 km<sup>2</sup>) (27% of the country's total) and are inhabited by more than 800,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Resguardos_Indígenas_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-Resguardos_Indígenas-301">[294]</a></sup> Some of the largest indigenous groups are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wayuu" title="Wayuu">Wayuu</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wayuu_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-wayuu-302">[295]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Paez_people" title="Paez people">Paez</a>, the Pastos, the <a href="/wiki/Ember%C3%A1_people" title="Emberá people">Emberá</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Zen%C3%BA" title="Zenú">Zenú</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pueblos_indígenas_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-pueblos_indígenas-303">[296]</a></sup> The departments of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Department_of_La_Guajira" title="Department of La Guajira">La Guajira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cauca_Department" title="Cauca Department">Cauca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nari%C3%B1o_Department" title="Nariño Department">Nariño</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba_Department" title="Córdoba Department">Córdoba</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sucre_Department" title="Sucre Department">Sucre</a> have the largest indigenous populations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-grupos_étnicos_1-3"><a href="#cite_note-grupos_étnicos-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Indigenous_Organization_of_Colombia" title="National Indigenous Organization of Colombia">Organización Nacional Indígena de Colombia</a> (ONIC), founded at the first National Indigenous Congress in 1982, is an organization representing the indigenous peoples of Colombia. In 1991, Colombia signed and ratified the current international law concerning indigenous peoples, <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_and_Tribal_Peoples_Convention,_1989" title="Indigenous and Tribal Peoples Convention, 1989">Indigenous and Tribal Peoples Convention, 1989</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ratifications_-_ilo.org_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ratifications_-_ilo.org-304">[297]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africans" title="Sub-Saharan Africans">Sub-Saharan Africans</a> were brought as <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">slaves</a>, mostly to the coastal lowlands, beginning early in the 16th century and continuing into the 19th century. Large Afro-Colombian communities are found today on the Pacific Coast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grupos_Étnicos_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-Grupos_Étnicos-305">[298]</a></sup> Numerous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jamaican_people" title="Jamaican people">Jamaicans</a> migrated mainly to the islands of San Andres and Providencia. A number of other Europeans and North Americans migrated to the country in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including people from the former <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">USSR</a> during and after the <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">Second World War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Extranjeros_en_Colombia_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-Extranjeros_en_Colombia-306">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Migraciones_Internacionales_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-Migraciones_Internacionales-307">[300]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many immigrant communities have settled on the Caribbean coast, in particular recent immigrants from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_West_Asia" title="Ethnic groups in West Asia">Middle East</a> and <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>. Barranquilla (the largest city of the Colombian Caribbean) and other Caribbean cities have the largest populations of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lebanese_Colombian" title="Lebanese Colombian">Lebanese</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palestinian_people" title="Palestinian people">Palestinian</a>, and other <a href="/wiki/Arab_Colombians" title="Arab Colombians">Levantines</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arab_colombians_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-arab_colombians-308">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[302]</a></sup> There are also important communities of <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Romanis</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Colombia" title="History of the Jews in Colombia">Jews</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombia_is_ethnically_diverse_296-1"><a href="#cite_note-Colombia_is_ethnically_diverse-296">[289]</a></sup> There is a major migration trend of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Venezuelan_people" title="Venezuelan people">Venezuelans</a>, due to the political and economic situation in Venezuela.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[303]</a></sup> In August 2019, Colombia offered citizenship to more than 24,000 children of Venezuelan refugees who were born in Colombia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[304]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Colombia" title="Religion in Colombia">Religion in Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Colombia" title="Freedom of religion in Colombia">Freedom of religion in Colombia</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jews_in_Colombia" title="Jews in Colombia">Jews in Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Santuario_de_Las_Lajas,_Ipiales,_Colombia,_2015-07-21,_DD_21-23_HDR.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2758" data-file-width="3958" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR.jpg/220px-Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR.jpg/330px-Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR.jpg/440px-Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Santuario_de_Las_Lajas,_Ipiales,_Colombia,_2015-07-21,_DD_21-23_HDR.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Las_Lajas_Sanctuary" title="Las Lajas Sanctuary">Las Lajas Sanctuary</a> in the southern Colombian Department of <a href="/wiki/Nari%C3%B1o_Department" title="Nariño Department">Nariño</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Administrative_Department_of_Statistics" title="National Administrative Department of Statistics">National Administrative Department of Statistics</a> (DANE) does not collect religious statistics, and accurate reports are difficult to obtain. However, based on various studies and a survey, about 90% of the population adheres to Christianity, the majority of which (70.9%–79%) are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" title="Roman Catholic">Roman Catholic</a>, while a significant minority (16.7%) adhere to <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> (primarily <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">Evangelicalism</a>). Some 4.7% of the population is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheist" title="Atheist">atheist</a> or agnostic, while 3.5% claim to believe in God but do not follow a specific religion. 1.8% of Colombians adhere to <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a> and <a href="/wiki/Adventism" title="Adventism">Adventism</a> and less than 1% adhere to other religions, such as the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="Baháʼí Faith">Baháʼí Faith</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, Judaism, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mormonism" title="Mormonism">Mormonism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Animism" title="Animism">Indigenous religions</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hare_Krishna_movement" title="Hare Krishna movement">Hare Krishna movement</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rastafari_movement" title="Rastafari movement">Rastafari movement</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>, and spiritual studies. The remaining people either did not respond or replied that they did not know. In addition to the above statistics, 35.9% of Colombians reported that they did not practice their faith actively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Religion_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-Religion-312">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Religion2_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-Religion2-313">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Religion_in_Latin_America_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-Religion_in_Latin_America-314">[307]</a></sup>
</p><p>While Colombia remains a mostly Roman Catholic country by <a href="/wiki/Baptism" title="Baptism">baptism</a> numbers, the 1991 Colombian constitution guarantees freedom of religion and all religious faiths and churches are equally free before the law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[308]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Colombia" title="Culture of Colombia">Culture of Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Festivals_in_Colombia" title="Festivals in Colombia">Festivals in Colombia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Colombian_folklore" title="Colombian folklore">Colombian folklore</a></div>
<p>Colombia lies at the crossroads of <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_culture" title="Latin American culture">Latin America</a> and the broader American continent, and as such has been hit by a wide range of cultural influences. <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">Native American</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Spain" title="Culture of Spain">Spanish</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Europe" title="Culture of Europe">European</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Africa" title="Culture of Africa">African</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States" title="Culture of the United States">American</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Caribbean" title="Culture of the Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Arab_culture" title="Arab culture">Middle Eastern</a> influences, as well as other Latin American cultural influences, are all present in Colombia's modern culture. Urban migration, industrialization, globalization, and other political, social and economic changes have also left an impression.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Many <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_Colombia" title="National symbols of Colombia">national symbols</a>, both objects and themes, have arisen from Colombia's diverse cultural traditions and aim to represent what Colombia, and the Colombian people, have in common. Cultural expressions in Colombia are promoted by the government through the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_(Colombia)" title="Ministry of Culture (Colombia)">Ministry of Culture</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Colombian_literature" title="Colombian literature">Colombian literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez,_2009.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1658" data-file-width="1820" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg/220px-Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg/330px-Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg/440px-Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez,_2009.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_in_Literature" title="List of Nobel laureates in Literature">Nobel literature</a> prize winner <a href="/wiki/Gabriel_Garc%C3%ADa_M%C3%A1rquez" title="Gabriel García Márquez">Gabriel García Márquez</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[309]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Colombian literature dates back to pre-Columbian era; a notable example of the period is the epic poem known as the <i>Legend of Yurupary</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Legend_of_Yurupary_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Legend_of_Yurupary-317">[310]</a></sup> In Spanish colonial times, notable writers include <a href="/wiki/Juan_de_Castellanos" title="Juan de Castellanos">Juan de Castellanos</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Eleg%C3%ADas_de_varones_ilustres_de_Indias" title="Elegías de varones ilustres de Indias">Elegías de varones ilustres de Indias</a></i>), Hernando Domínguez Camargo and his epic poem to San Ignacio de Loyola, <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Sim%C3%B3n" title="Pedro Simón">Pedro Simón</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juan_Rodr%C3%ADguez_Freyle" title="Juan Rodríguez Freyle">Juan Rodríguez Freyle</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/El_Carnero" title="El Carnero">El Carnero</a></i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[311]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lucas_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Piedrahita" title="Lucas Fernández de Piedrahita">Lucas Fernández de Piedrahita</a>, and the nun <a href="/wiki/Francisca_Josefa_de_la_Concepci%C3%B3n" title="Francisca Josefa de la Concepción">Francisca Josefa de Castillo</a>, representative of <a href="/wiki/Mysticism" title="Mysticism">mysticism</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Post-independence literature linked to Romanticism highlighted <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Nari%C3%B1o" title="Antonio Nariño">Antonio Nariño</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Fern%C3%A1ndez_Madrid" title="José Fernández Madrid">José Fernández Madrid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Camilo_Torres_Tenorio" title="Camilo Torres Tenorio">Camilo Torres Tenorio</a> and <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Antonio_Zea" title="Francisco Antonio Zea">Francisco Antonio Zea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[312]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[313]</a></sup> In the second half of the nineteenth century and early twentieth century the literary genre known as <i><a href="/wiki/Costumbrismo" title="Costumbrismo">costumbrismo</a></i> became popular; great writers of this period were <a href="/wiki/Tom%C3%A1s_Carrasquilla" title="Tomás Carrasquilla">Tomás Carrasquilla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Isaacs" title="Jorge Isaacs">Jorge Isaacs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Pombo" title="Rafael Pombo">Rafael Pombo</a> (the latter of whom wrote notable works of children's literature).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[314]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[315]</a></sup> Within that period, authors such as <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Asunci%C3%B3n_Silva" title="José Asunción Silva">José Asunción Silva</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Eustasio_Rivera" title="José Eustasio Rivera">José Eustasio Rivera</a>, <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_de_Greiff" title="León de Greiff">León de Greiff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porfirio_Barba-Jacob" title="Porfirio Barba-Jacob">Porfirio Barba-Jacob</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Vargas_Vila" title="José María Vargas Vila">José María Vargas Vila</a> developed the <a href="/wiki/Modernismo" title="Modernismo">modernist</a> movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[318]</a></sup> In 1872, Colombia established the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_Academy_of_Language" title="Colombian Academy of Language">Colombian Academy of Language</a>, the first Spanish language academy in the Americas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[319]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Candelario_Obeso" title="Candelario Obeso">Candelario Obeso</a> wrote the groundbreaking <i>Cantos Populares de mi Tierra</i> (1877), the first book of poetry by an Afro-Colombian author.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[320]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Candelario_Obeso_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-Candelario_Obeso-328">[321]</a></sup>
</p><p>Between 1939 and 1940 seven books of poetry were published under the name <i><a href="/wiki/Stone_and_Sky_(movement)" title="Stone and Sky (movement)">Stone and Sky</a></i> in the city of Bogotá that significantly impacted the country; they were edited by the poet Jorge Rojas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[322]</a></sup> In the following decade, <a href="/wiki/Gonzalo_Arango" title="Gonzalo Arango">Gonzalo Arango</a> founded the movement of "<a href="/wiki/Nadaism" title="Nadaism">nothingness</a>" in response to the violence of the time;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[323]</a></sup> he was influenced by <a href="/wiki/Nihilism" title="Nihilism">nihilism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Existentialism" title="Existentialism">existentialism</a>, and the thought of another great Colombian writer: <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Gonz%C3%A1lez_(writer)" title="Fernando González (writer)">Fernando González Ochoa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[324]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Boom" title="Latin American Boom">boom in Latin American literature</a>, successful writers emerged, led by <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel laureate</a> <a href="/wiki/Gabriel_Garc%C3%ADa_M%C3%A1rquez" title="Gabriel García Márquez">Gabriel García Márquez</a> and his magnum opus, <i><a href="/wiki/One_Hundred_Years_of_Solitude" title="One Hundred Years of Solitude">One Hundred Years of Solitude</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Caballero_Calder%C3%B3n" title="Eduardo Caballero Calderón">Eduardo Caballero Calderón</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Mej%C3%ADa_Vallejo" title="Manuel Mejía Vallejo">Manuel Mejía Vallejo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Mutis" title="Álvaro Mutis">Álvaro Mutis</a>, a writer who was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Miguel_de_Cervantes_Prize" title="Miguel de Cervantes Prize">Cervantes Prize</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prince_of_Asturias_Award_for_Letters" title="Prince of Asturias Award for Letters">Prince of Asturias Award for Letters</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[325]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[326]</a></sup> Other leading contemporary authors are <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Vallejo" title="Fernando Vallejo">Fernando Vallejo</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Ospina" title="William Ospina">William Ospina</a> (<a href="/wiki/R%C3%B3mulo_Gallegos_Prize" title="Rómulo Gallegos Prize">Rómulo Gallegos Prize</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Germ%C3%A1n_Castro_Caycedo" title="Germán Castro Caycedo">Germán Castro Caycedo</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Colombian_art" title="Colombian art">Colombian art</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:184px;max-width:184px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:182px;max-width:182px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2136" data-file-width="2965" decoding="async" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg/180px-AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg/270px-AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg/360px-AdamandEve-FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Work of the painter, and sculptor <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Botero" title="Fernando Botero">Fernando Botero</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:182px;max-width:182px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="275" data-file-width="330" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg/180px-Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg/270px-Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/28/Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Mural by <a href="/wiki/Santiago_Mart%C3%ADnez_Delgado" title="Santiago Martínez Delgado">Santiago Martínez Delgado</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Colombian art has over 3,000 years of history. Colombian artists have captured the country's changing political and cultural backdrop using a range of styles and mediums. There is archeological evidence of ceramics being produced earlier in Colombia than anywhere else in the Americas, dating as early as 3,000 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-donquijote.org_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-donquijote.org-334">[327]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artecolombiano_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-artecolombiano-335">[328]</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest examples of gold craftsmanship have been attributed to the Tumaco people<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[329]</a></sup> of the Pacific coast and date to around 325 BCE. Roughly between 200 BCE and 800 CE, the <a href="/wiki/San_Agust%C3%ADn,_Huila" title="San Agustín, Huila">San Agustín culture</a>, masters of <a href="/wiki/Stonemasonry" title="Stonemasonry">stonecutting</a>, entered its "classical period". They erected raised <a href="/wiki/Ceremony" title="Ceremony">ceremonial</a> centers, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sarcophagi" title="Sarcophagi">sarcophagi</a>, and large stone <a href="/wiki/Monolith" title="Monolith">monoliths</a> depicting <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anthropomorphic" title="Anthropomorphic">anthropomorphic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zoomorphism" title="Zoomorphism">zoomorphic</a> forms out of <a href="/wiki/Rock_(geology)" title="Rock (geology)">stone</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artecolombiano_335-1"><a href="#cite_note-artecolombiano-335">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-San_Agustín_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-San_Agustín-337">[330]</a></sup>
</p><p>Colombian art has followed the trends of the time, so during the 16th to 18th centuries, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Spain" title="Roman Catholicism in Spain">Spanish Catholicism</a> had a huge influence on Colombian art, and the popular <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">baroque</a> style was replaced with <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">rococo</a> when the Bourbons ascended to the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Spain" title="Monarchy of Spain">Spanish crown</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[331]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[332]</a></sup> More recently, Colombian artists <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Nel_G%C3%B3mez" title="Pedro Nel Gómez">Pedro Nel Gómez</a> and <a href="/wiki/Santiago_Mart%C3%ADnez_Delgado" title="Santiago Martínez Delgado">Santiago Martínez Delgado</a> started the Colombian Murial Movement in the 1940s, featuring the <a href="/wiki/Neoclassicism" title="Neoclassicism">neoclassical</a> features of <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-donquijote.org_334-1"><a href="#cite_note-donquijote.org-334">[327]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artecolombiano_335-2"><a href="#cite_note-artecolombiano-335">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[333]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[334]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Monumento_pantano_de_vargas,_completo._2006.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG/220px-Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG/330px-Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG/440px-Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Monumento_pantano_de_vargas,_completo._2006.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vargas_Swamp_Lancers" title="Vargas Swamp Lancers">Vargas Swamp Lancers</a>, artwork by <a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_Arenas_Betancourt" title="Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt">Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt</a></div></div></div>
<p>Since the 1950s, the Colombian art started to have a distinctive point of view, reinventing traditional elements under the concepts of the 20th century. Examples of this are the Greiff <a href="/wiki/Portrait" title="Portrait">portraits</a> by <a href="/wiki/Ignacio_G%C3%B3mez_Jaramillo" title="Ignacio Gómez Jaramillo">Ignacio Gómez Jaramillo</a>, showing what the Colombian art could do with the new techniques applied to typical Colombian themes. Carlos Correa, with his <a href="/wiki/Paradigm" title="Paradigm">paradigmatic</a> "Naturaleza muerta en silencio" (silent dead nature), combines geometrical <a href="/wiki/Abstraction_(art)" title="Abstraction (art)">abstraction</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cubism" title="Cubism">cubism</a>. <a href="/wiki/Alejandro_Obreg%C3%B3n" title="Alejandro Obregón">Alejandro Obregón</a> is often considered as the father of modern Colombian painting, and one of the most influential artist in this period, due to his originality, the painting of Colombian landscapes with <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(arts)" title="Symbolism (arts)">symbolic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Expressionism" title="Expressionism">expressionist</a> use of animals, (specially the <a href="/wiki/Andean_condor" title="Andean condor">Andean condor</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artecolombiano_335-3"><a href="#cite_note-artecolombiano-335">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[335]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[336]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Botero" title="Fernando Botero">Fernando Botero</a>, <a href="/wiki/Omar_Rayo" title="Omar Rayo">Omar Rayo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Grau" title="Enrique Grau">Enrique Grau</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89dgar_Negret" title="Édgar Negret">Édgar Negret</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Manzur" title="David Manzur">David Manzur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rodrigo_Arenas_Betancourt" title="Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt">Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Murillo_(artist)" title="Oscar Murillo (artist)">Oscar Murillo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Doris_Salcedo" title="Doris Salcedo">Doris Salcedo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Mu%C3%B1oz_(artist)" title="Oscar Muñoz (artist)">Oscar Muñoz</a> are some of the Colombian artists featured at the international level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-donquijote.org_334-2"><a href="#cite_note-donquijote.org-334">[327]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[337]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-museorayo_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-museorayo-346">[339]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Colombian sculpture from the sixteenth to 18th centuries was mostly devoted to <a href="/wiki/Religious_art" title="Religious art">religious depictions</a> of ecclesiastic art, strongly influenced by the Spanish schools of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sacred" title="Sacred">sacred</a> sculpture. During the early period of the Colombian republic, the national artists were focused in the production of sculptural portraits of politicians and public figures, in a plain <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neoclassicist" title="Neoclassicist">neoclassicist</a> trend.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[340]</a></sup> During the 20th century, the Colombian sculpture began to develop a bold and innovative work with the aim of reaching a better understanding of national sensitivity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artecolombiano_335-4"><a href="#cite_note-artecolombiano-335">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_sculptors_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_sculptors-348">[341]</a></sup>
