</p><p>Colombian photography was marked by the arrival of the <a href="/wiki/Daguerreotype" title="Daguerreotype">daguerreotype</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Louis_Gros" title="Jean-Baptiste Louis Gros">Jean-Baptiste Louis Gros</a> was who brought the daguerreotype process to Colombia in 1841. The Piloto public library has Latin America's largest archive of negatives, containing 1.7 million antique photographs covering Colombia 1848 until 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[342]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[343]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Colombian press has promoted the work of the <a href="/wiki/Cartoonist" title="Cartoonist">cartoonists</a>. In recent decades, <a href="/wiki/Fanzine" title="Fanzine">fanzines</a>, internet and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Independent_publisher" title="Independent publisher">independent publishers</a> have been fundamental to the growth of the comic in Colombia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[344]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[346]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Colombia" title="Architecture of Colombia">Architecture of Colombia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Muisca_architecture" title="Muisca architecture">Muisca architecture</a></div>
<p>Throughout the times, there have been a variety of <a href="/wiki/List_of_architectural_styles" title="List of architectural styles">architectural styles</a>, from those of indigenous peoples to contemporary ones, passing through colonial (military and religious), Republican, transition and modern styles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[347]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="771" data-file-width="1182" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg/220px-Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg/330px-Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg/440px-Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Historic Centre of <a href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz_de_Mompox" title="Santa Cruz de Mompox">Santa Cruz de Mompox</a>, an architectural site with colonial elements</div></div></div>
<p>Ancient habitation areas, longhouses, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Terrace_(agriculture)" title="Terrace (agriculture)">crop terraces</a>, roads as the <a href="/wiki/Inca_road_system" title="Inca road system">Inca road system</a>, cemeteries, <a href="/wiki/Hypogeum" title="Hypogeum">hypogeums</a> and <a href="/wiki/Necropolis" title="Necropolis">necropolises</a> are all part of the <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_architecture" title="Indigenous architecture">architectural heritage of indigenous peoples</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[348]</a></sup> Some prominent indigenous structures are the <a href="/wiki/Andean_preceramic" title="Andean preceramic">preceramic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ceramic" title="Ceramic">ceramic</a> archaeological site of <a href="/wiki/Tequendama" title="Tequendama">Tequendama</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[349]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tierradentro" title="Tierradentro">Tierradentro</a> (a park that contains the largest concentration of <a href="/wiki/List_of_pre-Columbian_cultures" title="List of pre-Columbian cultures">pre-Columbian</a> monumental <a href="/wiki/Shaft_tomb" title="Shaft tomb">shaft tombs</a> with side chambers),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[350]</a></sup> the largest collection of religious monuments and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Megalithic" title="Megalithic">megalithic</a> sculptures in South America, located in <a href="/wiki/San_Agust%C3%ADn_Archaeological_Park" title="San Agustín Archaeological Park">San Agustín, Huila</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-San_Agustín_337-1"><a href="#cite_note-San_Agustín-337">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[351]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Perdida" title="Ciudad Perdida">Lost city</a> (an archaeological site with a series of terraces carved into the mountainside, a net of tiled roads, and several circular plazas), and the large villages mainly built with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stone" title="Stone">stone</a>, wood, cane, and mud.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[352]</a></sup>
Architecture during the period of conquest and colonization is mainly derived of adapting <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_architecture" title="European architecture">European styles</a> to local conditions, and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_architecture" title="Spanish architecture">Spanish influence</a>, especially <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Extremadura" title="Extremadura">Extremaduran</a>, can be easily seen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[353]</a></sup> When Europeans founded cities two things were making simultaneously: the dimensioning of geometrical space (<a href="/wiki/Town_square" title="Town square">town square</a>, street), and the location of a tangible point of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Map_orientation" title="Map orientation">orientation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[354]</a></sup> The construction of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort" title="Fort">forts</a> was common throughout the Caribbean and in some cities of the interior, because of the dangers posed to Spanish colonial settlements from English, French and Dutch <a href="/wiki/Piracy_in_the_Caribbean" title="Piracy in the Caribbean">pirates</a> and hostile indigenous groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[355]</a></sup> Churches, chapels, schools, and hospitals belonging to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_religious_order" title="Catholic religious order">religious orders</a> cause a great urban impact.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1550–1750_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-1550–1750-363">[356]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Baroque_architecture" title="Baroque architecture">Baroque architecture</a> is used in military buildings and public spaces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[357]</a></sup> Marcelino Arroyo, <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Jos%C3%A9_de_Caldas" title="Francisco José de Caldas">Francisco José de Caldas</a> and Domingo de Petrés were great representatives of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neo-classical_architecture" title="Neo-classical architecture">neo-classical architecture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1550–1750_363-1"><a href="#cite_note-1550–1750-363">[356]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:240px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Plaza_Villa_de_Leyva.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2420" data-file-width="5472" decoding="async" height="105" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Plaza_Villa_de_Leyva.jpg/238px-Plaza_Villa_de_Leyva.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Plaza_Villa_de_Leyva.jpg/357px-Plaza_Villa_de_Leyva.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Plaza_Villa_de_Leyva.jpg/476px-Plaza_Villa_de_Leyva.jpg 2x" width="238"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Plaza_Villa_de_Leyva.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Villa_de_Leyva" title="Villa de Leyva">Villa de Leyva</a> main plaza</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Capitolio_Nacional" title="Capitolio Nacional">National Capitol</a> is a great representative of romanticism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[358]</a></sup> Wood was extensively used in doors, windows, railings, and ceilings during the colonization of <a href="/wiki/Antioquia_Department" title="Antioquia Department">Antioquia</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_region_of_Colombia" title="Caribbean region of Colombia">Caribbean</a> architecture acquires a strong <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_architecture" title="Arabic architecture">Arabic influence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[359]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Teatro_de_Crist%C3%B3bal_Col%C3%B3n" title="Teatro de Cristóbal Colón">Teatro Colón</a> in Bogotá is a lavish example of architecture from the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[360]</a></sup> The quintas houses with innovations in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volumetric" title="Volumetric">volumetric</a> conception are some of the best examples of the Republican architecture; the Republican action in the city focused on the design of three types of <a href="/wiki/Spatial_analysis" title="Spatial analysis">spaces</a>: parks with forests, small <a href="/wiki/Urban_park" title="Urban park">urban parks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Avenue_(landscape)" title="Avenue (landscape)">avenues</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gothic_architecture" title="Gothic architecture">Gothic style</a> was most commonly used for the design of churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[361]</a></sup>
</p><p>Deco style, <a href="/wiki/Rationalism_(architecture)" title="Rationalism (architecture)">modern neoclassicism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eclecticism_in_architecture" title="Eclecticism in architecture">eclecticism</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folklorist" title="Folklorist">folklorist</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Art_deco" title="Art deco">art deco</a> <a href="/wiki/Ornament_(art)" title="Ornament (art)">ornamental</a> resources significantly influenced the architecture of Colombia, especially during the transition period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[362]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/International_Style_(architecture)" title="International Style (architecture)">Modernism</a> contributed with new construction technologies and new <a href="/wiki/Building_material" title="Building material">materials</a> (steel, <a href="/wiki/Reinforced_concrete" title="Reinforced concrete">reinforced concrete</a>, glass and synthetic materials) and the <a href="/wiki/Topology" title="Topology">topology</a> architecture and <a href="/wiki/Concrete_slab" title="Concrete slab">lightened slabs system</a> also have a great influence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[363]</a></sup> The most influential architects of the modern movement were <a href="/wiki/Rogelio_Salmona" title="Rogelio Salmona">Rogelio Salmona</a> and Fernando Martínez Sanabria.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[364]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_architecture" title="Contemporary architecture">contemporary architecture</a> of Colombia is designed to give greater importance to the <a href="/wiki/Building_material" title="Building material">materials</a>, this architecture takes into account the specific <a href="/wiki/Geographical_feature" title="Geographical feature">natural and artificial geographies</a> and is also an architecture that appeals to the <a href="/wiki/Sense" title="Sense">senses</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[365]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Architectural_conservation" title="Architectural conservation">conservation of the architectural and urban heritage</a> of Colombia has been promoted in recent years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[366]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Colombia" title="Music of Colombia">Music of Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="12642" data-file-width="7180" decoding="async" height="299" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png/170px-Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png/255px-Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png/340px-Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Regions of Colombia by its traditional music.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tiple.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1926" data-file-width="921" decoding="async" height="356" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Tiple.jpg/170px-Tiple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Tiple.jpg/255px-Tiple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Tiple.jpg/340px-Tiple.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tiple.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Colombian_tiple" title="Colombian tiple">Colombian tiple</a></div></div></div>
<p>Colombia has a vibrant collage of talent that touches a full spectrum of <a href="/wiki/Rhythm" title="Rhythm">rhythms</a>. Musicians, composers, music producers and singers from Colombia are recognized internationally such as <a href="/wiki/Shakira" title="Shakira">Shakira</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juanes" title="Juanes">Juanes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Vives" title="Carlos Vives">Carlos Vives</a> and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[367]</a></sup> Colombian music blends European-influenced guitar and song structure with large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gaita_flutes" title="Gaita flutes">gaita flutes</a> and percussion instruments from the indigenous population, while its percussion structure and dance forms come from Africa. Colombia has a diverse and dynamic musical environment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-about.com_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-about.com-375">[368]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Guillermo_Uribe_Holgu%C3%ADn" title="Guillermo Uribe Holguín">Guillermo Uribe Holguín</a>, an important cultural figure in the <a href="/wiki/National_Symphony_Orchestra_of_Colombia" title="National Symphony Orchestra of Colombia">National Symphony Orchestra of Colombia</a>, Luis Antonio Calvo and Blas Emilio Atehortúa are some of the greatest exponents of the <a href="/wiki/Art_music" title="Art music">art music</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[369]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="Bogotá Philharmonic Orchestra">Bogotá Philharmonic Orchestra</a> is one of the most active orchestras in Colombia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[370]</a></sup>
</p><p>Caribbean music has many vibrant rhythms, such as <a href="/wiki/Cumbia_(Colombia)" title="Cumbia (Colombia)">cumbia</a> (it is played by the <a href="/wiki/Maraca" title="Maraca">maracas</a>, the drums, the gaitas and <a href="/wiki/Guacharaca" title="Guacharaca">guacharaca</a>), <a href="/wiki/Porro" title="Porro">porro</a> (it is a monotonous but joyful rhythm), <a href="/wiki/Mapal%C3%A9" title="Mapalé">mapalé</a> (with its fast rhythm and constant <a href="/wiki/Clapping" title="Clapping">clapping</a>) and the "<a href="/wiki/Vallenato" title="Vallenato">vallenato</a>", which originated in the northern part of the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> coast (the rhythm is mainly played by the caja, the guacharaca, and <a href="/wiki/Accordion" title="Accordion">accordion</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_music_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_music-378">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[372]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[375]</a></sup>
</p><p>The music from the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_coast" title="Pacific coast">Pacific coast</a>, such as the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Currulao_(music_genre)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Currulao (music genre) (page does not exist)">currulao</a>, is characterized by its strong use of drums (instruments such as the native <a href="/wiki/Marimba" title="Marimba">marimba</a>, the conunos, the <a href="/wiki/Bass_drum" title="Bass drum">bass drum</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Side_drum" title="Side drum">side drum</a>, and the cuatro guasas or tubular rattle). An important rhythm of the south region of the Pacific coast is the <a href="/wiki/Contradanza" title="Contradanza">contradanza</a> (it is used in dance shows due to the striking colours of the costumes).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_music_378-1"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_music-378">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[376]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[377]</a></sup> Marimba music, traditional chants and dances from the Colombia South Pacific region are on <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">UNESCO's Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[378]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[379]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[380]</a></sup>
</p><p>Important musical rhythms of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Andean_Region_(Colombia)" title="Andean Region (Colombia)">Andean Region</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Danza" title="Danza">danza</a> (dance of Andean folklore arising from the transformation of the European contredance), the <a href="/wiki/Bambuco" title="Bambuco">bambuco</a> (it is played with guitar, <a href="/wiki/Colombian_tiple" title="Colombian tiple">tiple</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[381]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Mandolin" title="Mandolin">mandolin</a>, the rhythm is danced by couples), the <a href="/wiki/Pasillo" title="Pasillo">pasillo</a> (a rhythm inspired by the Austrian <a href="/wiki/Waltz" title="Waltz">waltz</a> and the Colombian "danza", the lyrics have been composed by well-known poets), the guabina (the <a href="/wiki/Tiple" title="Tiple">tiple</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bandola" title="Bandola">bandola</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Requinto" title="Requinto">requinto</a> are the basic instruments), the <a href="/wiki/Sanjuanero" title="Sanjuanero">sanjuanero</a> (it originated in <a href="/wiki/Tolima_Department" title="Tolima Department">Tolima</a> and <a href="/wiki/Huila_Department" title="Huila Department">Huila</a> Departments, the rhythm is joyful and fast).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[382]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[384]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[385]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[386]</a></sup> Apart from these traditional rhythms, <a href="/wiki/Salsa_music" title="Salsa music">salsa music</a> has spread throughout the country, and the city of <a href="/wiki/Cali" title="Cali">Cali</a> is considered by many salsa singers to be 'The New Salsa Capital of the World'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_music_378-2"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_music-378">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[387]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[388]</a></sup>
</p><p>The instruments that distinguish the music of the <a href="/wiki/Orinoqu%C3%ADa_natural_region" title="Orinoquía natural region">Eastern Plains</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Harp" title="Harp">harp</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cuatro_(instrument)" title="Cuatro (instrument)">cuatro</a> (a type of four-stringed guitar) and maracas. Important rhythms of this region are the <a href="/wiki/Joropo" title="Joropo">joropo</a> (a fast rhythm and there is also tapping as a result of its <a href="/wiki/Flamenco" title="Flamenco">flamenco</a> ancestry) and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Galeron" title="Galeron">galeron</a> (it is heard a lot while <a href="/wiki/Cowboy" title="Cowboy">cowboys</a> are working).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_music_378-3"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_music-378">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[389]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[390]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[391]</a></sup>
</p><p>The music of the Amazon region is strongly influenced by the indigenous religious practices. Some of the musical instruments used are the manguaré (a musical instrument of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ceremonial" title="Ceremonial">ceremonial</a> type, consisting of a pair of large <a href="/wiki/Cylindrical_drum" title="Cylindrical drum">cylindrical drums</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Quena" title="Quena">quena</a> (melodic instrument), the <a href="/wiki/Rondador" title="Rondador">rondador</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Conga" title="Conga">congas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bell" title="Bell">bells</a>, and different types of flutes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[392]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[394]</a></sup>
</p><p>The music of the <a href="/wiki/Archipelago_of_San_Andr%C3%A9s,_Providencia_and_Santa_Catalina" title="Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina">Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina</a> is usually accompanied by a <a href="/wiki/Mandolin" title="Mandolin">mandolin</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Washtub_bass" title="Washtub bass">tub-bass</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Jawbone_(instrument)" title="Jawbone (instrument)">jawbone</a>, a guitar and <a href="/wiki/Maraca" title="Maraca">maracas</a>. Some popular archipelago rhythms are the <a href="/wiki/Schottische" title="Schottische">Schottische</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Calypso_music" title="Calypso music">Calypso</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Polka" title="Polka">Polka</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mento" title="Mento">Mento</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[395]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[396]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Popular_culture">Popular culture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Theater_of_Colombia" title="Theater of Colombia">Theater of Colombia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Colombia" title="Cinema of Colombia">Cinema of Colombia</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_of_Colombia" title="Media of Colombia">Media of Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg/180px-Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg/270px-Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg/360px-Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Teatro Colón of Bogotá houses the Ibero-American Theater Festival of Bogotá, one of the biggest theater festivals in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Theater_Festival_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-Theater_Festival-404">[397]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Theater was introduced in Colombia during the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">Spanish colonization</a> in 1550 through <a href="/wiki/Zarzuela" title="Zarzuela">zarzuela</a> companies. Colombian theater is supported by the Ministry of Culture and a number of private and state owned organizations. The <a href="/wiki/Theater_of_Colombia" title="Theater of Colombia">Ibero-American Theater Festival of Bogotá</a> is the cultural event of the highest importance in Colombia and one of the biggest theater festivals in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Theater_Festival_404-1"><a href="#cite_note-Theater_Festival-404">[397]</a></sup> Other important theater events are: The Festival of Puppet The Fanfare (Medellín), The Manizales Theater Festival, The Caribbean Theatre Festival (Santa Marta) and The Art Festival of Popular Culture "Cultural Invasion" (Bogotá).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Theatre_in_Colombia_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-Theatre_in_Colombia-405">[398]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theatrical_production_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-theatrical_production-406">[399]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-teatro_siglo_XX_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-teatro_siglo_XX-407">[400]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although the <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Colombia" title="Cinema of Colombia">Colombian cinema</a> is young as an industry, more recently the film industry was growing with support from the Film Act passed in 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-the_Film_Act_passed_in_2003_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-the_Film_Act_passed_in_2003-408">[401]</a></sup> Many film festivals take place in Colombia, but the two most important are the <a href="/wiki/Cartagena_Film_Festival" title="Cartagena Film Festival">Cartagena Film Festival</a>, which is the oldest film festival in Latin America, and the <a href="/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1_Film_Festival" title="Bogotá Film Festival">Bogotá Film Festival</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fiapf_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-fiapf-409">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-film_festivals_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-film_festivals-410">[403]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[404]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1283" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG/200px-Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG/300px-Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG/400px-Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Cartagena_Film_Festival" title="Cartagena Film Festival">Cartagena Film Festival</a> is the oldest cinema event in Latin America. The central focus is on films from Ibero-America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fiapf_409-1"><a href="#cite_note-fiapf-409">[402]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Some important national circulation newspapers are <i><a href="/wiki/El_Tiempo_(Colombia)" title="El Tiempo (Colombia)">El Tiempo</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/El_Espectador" title="El Espectador">El Espectador</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Colombia" title="Television in Colombia">Television in Colombia</a> has two privately owned TV networks and three state-owned TV networks with national coverage, as well as six regional TV networks and dozens of local TV stations. Private channels, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RCN_TV" title="RCN TV">RCN</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caracol_Televisi%C3%B3n" title="Caracol Televisión">Caracol</a> are the highest-rated. The regional channels and regional newspapers cover a department or more and its content is made in these particular areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Television_in_Colombia_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-Television_in_Colombia-412">[405]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-press_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-press-413">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_press_in_Colombia_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_press_in_Colombia-414">[407]</a></sup>
</p><p>Colombia has three major national <a href="/wiki/Radio_in_Colombia" title="Radio in Colombia">radio networks</a>: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radiodifusora_Nacional_de_Colombia" title="Radiodifusora Nacional de Colombia">Radiodifusora Nacional de Colombia</a>, a state-run national radio; <a href="/wiki/Caracol_Radio" title="Caracol Radio">Caracol Radio</a> and <a href="/wiki/RCN_Radio" title="RCN Radio">RCN Radio</a>, privately owned networks with hundreds of affiliates. There are other national networks, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cadena_Super" title="Cadena Super">Cadena Super</a>, <a href="/wiki/Todelar" title="Todelar">Todelar</a>, and Colmundo. Many hundreds of radio stations are registered with the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Information_Technologies_and_Communications_(Colombia)" title="Ministry of Information Technologies and Communications (Colombia)">Ministry of Information Technologies and Communications</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Radio_in_Colombia_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-Radio_in_Colombia-415">[408]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Colombian_cuisine" title="Colombian cuisine">Colombian cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="320" data-file-width="630" decoding="async" height="112" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg/220px-Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg/330px-Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg/440px-Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sancocho de gallina criolla is a traditional soup in Colombia.</div></div></div>
<p>Colombia's varied cuisine is influenced by its diverse fauna and flora as well as the cultural traditions of the ethnic groups. Colombian dishes and ingredients vary widely by region. Some of the most common ingredients are: cereals such as rice and maize; tubers such as potato and <a href="/wiki/Cassava" title="Cassava">cassava</a>; assorted <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legumes</a>; meats, including beef, chicken, pork and goat; fish; and seafood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paseo_de_olla_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-Paseo_de_olla-416">[409]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[410]</a></sup> Colombia cuisine also features a variety of tropical fruits such as <a href="/wiki/Physalis_peruviana" title="Physalis peruviana">cape gooseberry</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acca_sellowiana" title="Acca sellowiana">feijoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eugenia_stipitata" title="Eugenia stipitata">arazá</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pitaya" title="Pitaya">dragon fruit</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Purple_mangosteen" title="Purple mangosteen">mangostino</a>, <a href="/wiki/Passiflora_ligularis" title="Passiflora ligularis">granadilla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Papaya" title="Papaya">papaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guava" title="Guava">guava</a>, mora (<a href="/wiki/Blackberry" title="Blackberry">blackberry</a>), <a href="/wiki/Solanum_quitoense" title="Solanum quitoense">lulo</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Annona_muricata" title="Annona muricata">soursop</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Passionfruit" title="Passionfruit">passionfruit</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_cuisine_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_cuisine-418">[411]</a></sup> Colombia is one of the world's largest consumers of fruit juices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[412]</a></sup>
</p><p>Among the most representative appetizers and soups are <a href="/wiki/Tostones" title="Tostones">patacones</a> (fried green plantains), <a href="/wiki/Sancocho" title="Sancocho">sancocho</a> de gallina (chicken soup with root vegetables) and <a href="/wiki/Ajiaco" title="Ajiaco">ajiaco</a> (potato and corn soup). Representative snacks and breads are <a href="/wiki/Pandebono" title="Pandebono">pandebono</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arepa" title="Arepa">arepas</a> (corn cakes), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aborrajado" title="Aborrajado">aborrajados</a> (fried sweet plantains with cheese), <a href="/wiki/Torta" title="Torta">torta</a> de <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Choclo" title="Choclo">choclo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Empanada" title="Empanada">empanadas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Almoj%C3%A1bana" title="Almojábana">almojábanas</a>. Representative main courses are <a href="/wiki/Bandeja_paisa" title="Bandeja paisa">bandeja paisa</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lechona_tolimense" title="Lechona tolimense">lechona tolimense</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ternera_a_la_llanera" title="Ternera a la llanera">mamona</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tamales" title="Tamales">tamales</a> and fish dishes (such as <a href="/wiki/Arroz_de_lisa" title="Arroz de lisa">arroz de lisa</a>), especially in coastal regions where <a href="/wiki/Kibbeh" title="Kibbeh">kibbeh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suero" title="Suero">suero</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coste%C3%B1o_cheese" title="Costeño cheese">costeño cheese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carima%C3%B1ola" title="Carimañola">carimañolas</a> are also eaten. Representative side dishes are papas chorreadas (potatoes with cheese), remolachas rellenas con huevo duro (beets stuffed with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hard-boiled_egg" title="Hard-boiled egg">hard-boiled egg</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Coconut_rice" title="Coconut rice">arroz con coco</a> (coconut rice).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_cuisine_418-1"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_cuisine-418">[411]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paseo_de_olla_416-1"><a href="#cite_note-Paseo_de_olla-416">[409]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Organic_food" title="Organic food">Organic food</a> is a current trend in big cities, although in general across the country the fruits and veggies are very natural and fresh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[413]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_Food_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_Food-421">[414]</a></sup>
</p><p>Representative desserts are <a href="/wiki/Bu%C3%B1uelo" title="Buñuelo">buñuelos</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natilla" title="Natilla">natillas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maria_Luisa_cake" title="Maria Luisa cake">Maria Luisa cake</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bocadillo_(dessert)" title="Bocadillo (dessert)">bocadillo</a> made of guayaba (guava jelly), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cocadas" title="Cocadas">cocadas</a> (coconut balls), casquitos de guayaba (candied guava peels), <a href="/wiki/Torta_de_nata" title="Torta de nata">torta de natas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oblea" title="Oblea">obleas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cr%C3%A8me_caramel" title="Crème caramel">flan</a> de <a href="/wiki/Mango" title="Mango">mango</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rosc%C3%B3n" title="Roscón">roscón</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Milhoja" title="Milhoja">milhoja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manjar_blanco" title="Manjar blanco">manjar blanco</a>, dulce de <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feijoa" title="Feijoa">feijoa</a>, dulce de <a href="/wiki/Mountain_papaya" title="Mountain papaya">papayuela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Torta" title="Torta">torta</a> de mojicón, and esponjado de <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Curuba" title="Curuba">curuba</a>. Typical sauces (salsas) are <a href="/wiki/Hogao" title="Hogao">hogao</a> (tomato and onion sauce) and Colombian-style <a href="/wiki/Aj%C3%AD_(sauce)" title="Ají (sauce)">ají</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_cuisine_418-2"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_cuisine-418">[411]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paseo_de_olla_416-2"><a href="#cite_note-Paseo_de_olla-416">[409]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some representative beverages are <a href="/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Colombia" title="Coffee production in Colombia">coffee</a> (Tinto), <a href="/wiki/Champ%C3%BAs" title="Champús">champús</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cholado" title="Cholado">cholado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lulada" title="Lulada">lulada</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avena_(beverage)" title="Avena (beverage)">avena</a> colombiana, <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a> juice, <a href="/wiki/Aguapanela" title="Aguapanela">aguapanela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aguardiente" title="Aguardiente">aguardiente</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hot_chocolate" title="Hot chocolate">hot chocolate</a> and fresh fruit juices (often made with water or milk).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_cuisine_418-3"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_cuisine-418">[411]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paseo_de_olla_416-3"><a href="#cite_note-Paseo_de_olla-416">[409]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Colombia" title="Sport in Colombia">Sport in Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rio_2016._Ciclismo_BMX-BMX_Cycling_(29016608602).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3056" data-file-width="4592" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Rio_2016._Ciclismo_BMX-BMX_Cycling_%2829016608602%29.jpg/220px-Rio_2016._Ciclismo_BMX-BMX_Cycling_%2829016608602%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Rio_2016._Ciclismo_BMX-BMX_Cycling_%2829016608602%29.jpg/330px-Rio_2016._Ciclismo_BMX-BMX_Cycling_%2829016608602%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Rio_2016._Ciclismo_BMX-BMX_Cycling_%2829016608602%29.jpg/440px-Rio_2016._Ciclismo_BMX-BMX_Cycling_%2829016608602%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rio_2016._Ciclismo_BMX-BMX_Cycling_(29016608602).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mariana_Paj%C3%B3n" title="Mariana Pajón">Mariana Pajón</a> is a Colombian cyclist, two-time Olympic gold medalist and <a href="/wiki/UCI_BMX_World_Championships" title="UCI BMX World Championships">BMX World Champion</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tejo_(sport)" title="Tejo (sport)">Tejo</a> is Colombia's national sport and is a team sport that involves launching projectiles to hit a target.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tejo-Colombia's_national_sport._422-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tejo-Colombia's_national_sport.-422">[415]</a></sup> But of all sports in Colombia, <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> is the most popular. <a href="/wiki/Colombia_national_football_team" title="Colombia national football team">Colombia</a> was the champion of the <a href="/wiki/2001_Copa_Am%C3%A9rica" title="2001 Copa América">2001 Copa América</a>, in which they set a new record of being undefeated, conceding no goals and winning each match. Colombia has been awarded "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Rankings#Best_Mover_of_the_Year" title="FIFA World Rankings">mover of the year</a>" twice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[416]</a></sup>
</p><p>Colombia is a hub for <a href="/wiki/Inline_speed_skating" title="Inline speed skating">roller skaters</a>. The national team is a perennial powerhouse at the World Roller Speed Skating Championships.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Patinaje_colombiano_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-Patinaje_colombiano-424">[417]</a></sup> Colombia has traditionally been very good in <a href="/wiki/Cycle_sport" title="Cycle sport">cycling</a> and a large number of Colombian cyclists have triumphed in major competitions of cycling.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_cycling_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_cycling-425">[418]</a></sup>
</p><p>Baseball is popular in cities like <a href="/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia" title="Cartagena, Colombia">Cartagena</a> and <a href="/wiki/Barranquilla" title="Barranquilla">Barranquilla</a>. Of those cities have come good players like: <a href="/wiki/Orlando_Cabrera" title="Orlando Cabrera">Orlando Cabrera</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%89dgar_Renter%C3%ADa" title="Édgar Rentería">Édgar Rentería</a>, who was champion of the <a href="/wiki/World_Series" title="World Series">World Series</a> in <a href="/wiki/1997_World_Series" title="1997 World Series">1997</a> and <a href="/wiki/2010_World_Series" title="2010 World Series">2010</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[419]</a></sup> and others who have played in <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>. Colombia was <a href="/wiki/Baseball_World_Cup" title="Baseball World Cup">world amateur champion</a> in 1947 and 1965.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-béisbolglorias_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-béisbolglorias-427">[420]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">Boxing</a> is one of the sports that has produced more world champions for Colombia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-History_of_boxing_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-History_of_boxing-428">[421]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boxing_champions_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boxing_champions-429">[422]</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Motorsport" title="Motorsport">Motorsports</a> also occupies an important place in the sporting preferences of Colombians; <a href="/wiki/Juan_Pablo_Montoya" title="Juan Pablo Montoya">Juan Pablo Montoya</a> is a race car driver known for winning 7 Formula One events. Colombia also has excelled in sports such as <a href="/wiki/UCI_BMX_World_Championships" title="UCI BMX World Championships">BMX</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judo" title="Judo">judo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shooting_sports" title="Shooting sports">shooting sport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taekwondo" title="Taekwondo">taekwondo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wrestling" title="Wrestling">wrestling</a>, <a href="/wiki/High_diving" title="High diving">high diving</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sport_of_athletics" title="Sport of athletics">athletics</a>, also has a long tradition in <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">weightlifting</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bowling" title="Bowling">bowling</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[423]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[424]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[425]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Colombia" title="Health care in Colombia">Health care in Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Complejo_M%C3%A9dico_-_Hospital_Internacional_de_Colombia_HIC.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2242" data-file-width="3992" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Complejo_M%C3%A9dico_-_Hospital_Internacional_de_Colombia_HIC.jpg/220px-Complejo_M%C3%A9dico_-_Hospital_Internacional_de_Colombia_HIC.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Complejo_M%C3%A9dico_-_Hospital_Internacional_de_Colombia_HIC.jpg/330px-Complejo_M%C3%A9dico_-_Hospital_Internacional_de_Colombia_HIC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Complejo_M%C3%A9dico_-_Hospital_Internacional_de_Colombia_HIC.jpg/440px-Complejo_M%C3%A9dico_-_Hospital_Internacional_de_Colombia_HIC.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Complejo_M%C3%A9dico_-_Hospital_Internacional_de_Colombia_HIC.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Colombia leads the annual <i><a href="/wiki/Am%C3%A9rica_Econom%C3%ADa" title="América Economía">América Economía</a></i> ranking of the best clinics and hospitals in Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_clinics_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_clinics-433">[426]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The overall <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> in Colombia at birth is 79.3 years (76.7 years for males and 81.9 years for females).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Life_expectancy_at_birth_288-1"><a href="#cite_note-Life_expectancy_at_birth-288">[281]</a></sup> Healthcare reforms have led to massive improvements in the healthcare systems of the country, with health standards in Colombia improving very much since the 1980s. The new system has widened population coverage by the social and health security system from 21% (pre-1993) to 96% in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[427]</a></sup>
</p><p>A study conducted by <i><a href="/wiki/Am%C3%A9rica_Econom%C3%ADa" title="América Economía">América Economía</a></i> magazine ranked 21 Colombian <a href="/wiki/Health_facility" title="Health facility">health care institutions</a> among the top 44 in Latin America, amounting to 48 percent of the total.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colombian_clinics_433-1"><a href="#cite_note-Colombian_clinics-433">[426]</a></sup> In 2017, the government declared a <a href="/wiki/Cancer_research" title="Cancer research">cancer research</a> and treatment center as a Project of National Strategic Interest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[428]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Colombia" title="Education in Colombia">Education in Colombia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG/200px-UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG/300px-UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG/400px-UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>M5 building – <a href="/wiki/National_University_of_Colombia" title="National University of Colombia">National University of Colombia</a>, designed by <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Nel_G%C3%B3mez" title="Pedro Nel Gómez">Pedro Nel Gómez</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Universidad_de_los_Andes_(3326108271).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg/200px-Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg/300px-Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg/400px-Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Universidad_de_los_Andes_(3326108271).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mario Laserna Building – <a href="/wiki/University_of_Los_Andes_(Colombia)" title="University of Los Andes (Colombia)">University of Los Andes</a></div></div></div>
<p>The educational experience of many Colombian children begins with attendance at a <a href="/wiki/Preschool" title="Preschool">preschool</a> academy until age five (<i>Educación preescolar</i>). Basic education (<i>Educación básica</i>) is compulsory by law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[429]</a></sup> It has two stages: Primary basic education (<i>Educación básica primaria</i>) which goes from first to fifth grade – children from six to ten years old, and Secondary basic education (<i>Educación básica secundaria</i>), which goes from sixth to ninth grade. Basic education is followed by Middle vocational education (<i>Educación media vocacional</i>) that comprises the tenth and eleventh grades. It may have different vocational training modalities or specialties (academic, technical, business, and so on.) according to the curriculum adopted by each school.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sistema_educativo_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-sistema_educativo-437">[430]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the successful completion of all the basic and middle education years, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-school_diploma" title="High-school diploma">high-school diploma</a> is awarded. The high-school graduate is known as a <i>bachiller</i>, because secondary basic school and middle education are traditionally considered together as a unit called <i>bachillerato</i> (sixth to eleventh grade). Students in their final year of middle education take the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ICFES_Examination" title="ICFES Examination">ICFES test</a> (now renamed Saber 11) to gain access to higher education (<i>Educación superior</i>). This higher education includes undergraduate professional studies, technical, technological and intermediate professional education, and post-graduate studies. Technical professional institutions of Higher Education are also opened to students holder of a qualification in Arts and Business. This qualification is usually awarded by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Service_of_Learning_(Colombia)" title="National Service of Learning (Colombia)">SENA</a> after a two years curriculum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[431]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Bachilleres</i> (high-school graduates) may enter into a professional undergraduate career program offered by a university; these programs last up to five years (or less for technical, technological and intermediate professional education, and post-graduate studies), even as much to six to seven years for some careers, such as medicine. In Colombia, there is not an institution such as college; students go directly into a career program at a university or any other educational institution to obtain a professional, technical or technological title. Once graduated from the university, people are granted a (professional, technical or technological) diploma and licensed (if required) to practice the career they have chosen. For some professional career programs, students are required to take the Saber-Pro test, in their final year of undergraduate academic education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sistema_educativo_437-1"><a href="#cite_note-sistema_educativo-437">[430]</a></sup>
</p><p>Public spending on education as a proportion of gross domestic product in 2015 was 4.49%. This represented 15.05% of total government expenditure. The <a href="/wiki/Gross_enrolment_ratio" title="Gross enrolment ratio">primary and secondary gross enrolment ratios</a> stood at 113.56% and 98.09% respectively. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/School-life_expectancy" title="School-life expectancy">School-life expectancy</a> was 14.42 years. A total of 94.58% of the population aged 15 and older were recorded as literate, including 98.66% of those aged 15–24.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNESCO_290-1"><a href="#cite_note-UNESCO-290">[283]</a></sup>
</p>

</li>
</ol></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="reflist">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">IPA transcription of "<i>República de Colombia</i>": <small>Spanish pronunciation: </small><span class="IPA" lang="es-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">[reˈpuβlika ðe koˈlombja]</a></span>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Balboa is best known for being the first European to see the Pacific Ocean in 1513, which he called <i>Mar del Sur</i> (or "Sea of the South") and would facilitate Spanish exploration and settlement of South America.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-62">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A royal decree of 1713 approved the legality of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palenque_de_San_Basilio" title="Palenque de San Basilio">Palenque de San Basilio</a> founded by runaway slaves as a refuge in the seventeenth century. The people of San Basilio fought against slavery, thereby giving rise to the first free place in the Americas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[57]</a></sup> Its main leader was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benkos_Bioho" title="Benkos Bioho">Benkos Biohó</a>, who was born in West Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[58]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-65"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-65">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Peter_Claver" title="Peter Claver">Peter Claver</a> was a Spaniard who traveled to Cartagena in 1610 and was ordained as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesuit" title="Jesuit">Jesuit</a> priest in 1616. Claver cared for African slaves for thirty-eight years, defending their lives and the <a href="/wiki/Dignity" title="Dignity">dignity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[60]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-121"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-121">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/H%C3%A9ctor_Abad_G%C3%B3mez" title="Héctor Abad Gómez">Héctor Abad</a> was a prominent medical doctor, university professor, and human rights leader whose holistic vision of healthcare led him to found the Colombian National School of Public Health. The increasing violence and human rights abuses of the 1970s and 1980s led him to fight for social justice in his community.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[114]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[115]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-123"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-123">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Javier_de_Nicol%C3%B3" title="Javier de Nicoló">Javier de Nicoló</a> was a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salesian" title="Salesian">Salesian</a> priest who grew up in war-torn Italy and arrived in Colombia a year after the bogotazo. He developed a program that has offered more than 40,000 young people the education and moral support they needed to become productive citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[116]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SURFACE_WATER#" rel="nofollow">"Surface water and surface water change"</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD)<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJohn_Huxtable_Elliott2007">John Huxtable Elliott (2007). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Q6ucuphGA3YC&amp;pg=PA124" rel="nofollow"><i>Empires of the Atlantic World: Britain and Spain in America, 1492–1830</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-69"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-69">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJaime_U._JaramilloAdolfo_R._MaiselMiguel_M._Urrutia1997">Jaime U. <li id="cite_note-95"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-95">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/colombia" rel="nofollow">"Colombia"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">The World Factbook</a></i> (2022 ed.). <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">Central Intelligence Agency</a>. 12 January 2022.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+World+Factbook&amp;rft.atitle=Colombia&amp;rft.date=2022-01-12&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cia.gov%2Fthe-world-factbook%2Fcountries%2Fcolombia&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AColombia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-HistoriaConstitucional-96"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-HistoriaConstitucional_96-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-HistoriaConstitucional_96-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFEdgar_Arana">Edgar Arana. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150327033803/http://unilibrepereira.edu.co/catehortua/posgrados/archivos2/HISTORIA%20CONSTITUCIONAL%20COLOMBIANA.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Historia Constitucional Colombiana"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> (in Spanish). Universidad Libre Seccional Pereira. <li id="cite_note-Encarta-108"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Encarta_108-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1" id="CITEREFCharles_BergquistDavid_J._Robinson1997–2005">Charles Bergquist; David J. Robinson (1997–2005). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071111194946/http://ca.encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761564636_10/Colombia.html" rel="nofollow">"Colombia"</a>. <i>Microsoft Encarta Online Encyclopedia 2005</i>. Microsoft Corporation. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://ca.encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761564636_10/Colombia.html" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 11 November 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">16 April</span> 2006</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Colombia&amp;rft.btitle=Microsoft+Encarta+Online+Encyclopedia+2005&amp;rft.pub=Microsoft+Corporation&amp;rft.date=1997%2F2005&amp;rft.au=Charles+Bergquist&amp;rft.au=David+J.+Robinson&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fca.encarta.msn.com%2Fencyclopedia_761564636_10%2FColombia.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AColombia"></span> <i>On 9 April 1948, Gaitán was assassinated outside his law offices in downtown Bogotá. The assassination marked the start of a decade of bloodshed, called </i>La Violencia<i> (The Violence), which took the lives of an estimated 180,000 Colombians before it subsided in 1958.</i></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Colombia's_legacy_with_Korea-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Colombia's_legacy_with_Korea_109-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFCarlos_Horacio_Urán1986">Carlos Horacio Urán (1986). <a class="external text" href="http://kellogg.nd.edu/publications/workingpapers/WPS/069.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Colombia y los Estados Unidos en la Guerra de Corea"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> (in Spanish). The Kellogg Institute for International Studies. <a class="external text" href="https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221009/http://kellogg.nd.edu/publications/workingpapers/WPS/069.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 9 October 2022.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Colombia+y+los+Estados+Unidos+en+la+Guerra+de+Corea&amp;rft.pub=The+Kellogg+Institute+for+International+Studies&amp;rft.date=1986&amp;rft.au=Carlos+Horacio+Ur%C3%A1n&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fkellogg.nd.edu%2Fpublications%2Fworkingpapers%2FWPS%2F069.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AColombia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-110"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-110">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFAtehortúa_Cruz2010">Atehortúa Cruz, Adolfo (2 February 2010). <a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.17227%2F01234870.31folios33.48" rel="nofollow">"El golpe de Rojas y el poder de los militares"</a> [Rojas’ coup d’etat and the power of army men]. <i>Folios</i> (in Spanish). <b>1</b> (31): 33–48. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.17227%2F01234870.31folios33.48" rel="nofollow">10.17227/01234870.31folios33.48</a></span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Folios&amp;rft.atitle=El+golpe+de+Rojas+y+el+poder+de+los+militares&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=31&amp;rft.pages=33-48&amp;rft.date=2010-02-02&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.17227%2F01234870.31folios33.48&amp;rft.aulast=Atehort%C3%BAa+Cruz&amp;rft.aufirst=Adolfo&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.17227%252F01234870.31folios33.48&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AColombia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-111"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-111">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFAyala_Diago,_César_Augusto2000">Ayala Diago, César Augusto (2000). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170424112356/http://www.banrepcultural.org/blaavirtual/revistas/credencial/marzo2000/123gustavo.htm" rel="nofollow">"Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, 100 años, 1900–1975"</a> (in Spanish). <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_the_Republic_(Colombia)" title="Bank of the Republic (Colombia)">Banco de la República</a>. <li id="cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-162"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_162-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFGranthamDuncanEvansJones2020">Grantham, H. E. M. (2020). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7723057" rel="nofollow">"Anthropogenic modification of forests means only 40% of remaining forests have high ecosystem integrity – Supplementary Material"</a>. <i>Nature Communications</i>. <b>11</b> (1): 5978. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external <li id="cite_note-183"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-183">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLandau2017">Landau, David (2017). <i>Colombian Constitutional Law: Leading Cases</i>. Oxford University Press. p. 217. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780190640378" title="Special:BookSources/9780190640378"><bdi>9780190640378</bdi></a>. <q>The 1991 Constitution moved Colombia away from the inquisitorial criminal system that it has traditionally possessed (and where the judge plays the leading role in the criminal process), and toward an adversarial system more like the American system, where lawyers act for each side as the protagonists.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Colombian+Constitutional+Law%3A+Leading+Cases&amp;rft.pages=217&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.isbn=9780190640378&amp;rft.aulast=Landau&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AColombia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-184"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-184">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFIpsos-Napoleon_Franco_poll2009">Ipsos-Napoleon Franco poll (1 June 2009). <a class="external text" href="http://www.semana.com/politica/articulo/si-no-uribe-santos/103711-3" rel="nofollow">"Si no es Uribe, es Santos"</a> (in Spanish). semana.com<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-202"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-202">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.sipri.org/sites/default/files/Milex-share-of-GDP.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Military expenditure (% of GDP)"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. sipri.org. <a class="external text" href="https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221009/https://www.sipri.org/sites/default/files/Milex-share-of-GDP.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 9 October 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-203"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-203">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&amp;mtdsg_no=XXVI-9&amp;chapter=26&amp;clang=_en" rel="nofollow">"Chapter XXVI: Disarmament – No. 9 Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons"</a>. <li id="cite_note-318"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-318">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://sites.google.com/site/cursodeliteraturacolombiana/unidad-2/los-cronistas" rel="nofollow">"Cronistas del Nuevo Reino de Granada"</a>. ihlc.udea.edu.co<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-artecolombiano-335"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-artecolombiano_335-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-artecolombiano_335-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-artecolombiano_335-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-artecolombiano_335-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-artecolombiano_335-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFFrancisco_Gil_Tovar1985">Francisco Gil Tovar (1985). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=fre20PtG-ZAC&amp;pg=PP1" rel="nofollow"><i>El arte colombiano. Plaza y Janes Editores Colombia s.a. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-958-14-0016-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-958-14-0016-4"><bdi>978-958-14-0016-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=El+arte+colombiano.+Volume+3+of+Selecci%C3%B3n+Cultura+colombiana&amp;rft.pub=Plaza+y+Janes+Editores+Colombia+s.a&amp;rft.date=1985&amp;rft.isbn=978-958-14-0016-4&amp;rft.au=Francisco+Gil+Tovar&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dfre20PtG-ZAC%26pg%3DPP1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AColombia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-351"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-351">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREFPablo_Guerra">Pablo Guerra. <a class="external text" href="http://www.elespectador.com/noticias/cultura/entender-los-comics-colombia-articulo-516194" rel="nofollow">"Para entender los cómics en Colombia"</a> (in Spanish). elespectador.com<span class="reference-accessdate">. <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="General_information">General information</span></h3>
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Colombia" rel="nofollow">Colombia</a> at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Britannica.com" title="Britannica.com">Britannica.com</a></li>

Vol. 6 (11th ed.). pp. 700–713.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Colombia&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.pages=700-713&amp;rft.edition=11th&amp;rft.date=1911&amp;rft.aulast=Lamoureux&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew+Jackson&amp;rft.au=Edmundson%2C+George&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AColombia"></span></li>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<ul><li><span class="languageicon">(in Spanish)</span> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180819182205/https://www.nomasfilas.gov.co/" rel="nofollow">Colombia Online Government website</a></li></ul>
